pages.headline: Give Abu Hamza the boot
pages.teaser: A NINE-YEAR fight to ship the hate preacher to US on terror charges is coming to a head
pages.byline: By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor, and AMBER ELLIOTT
pages.articlebody:
HOOK-handed hate cleric Abu Hamza must be kicked out of Britain TODAY, angry MPs demanded last night.

A nine-year fight to ship Hamza, 53, to the US on terror charges comes to a head this morning.

But fed-up Tories say Britain should defy European judges and extradite him — even if they rule he can stay.

The fanatical hook-handed Muslim cleric will learn today if he has won a legal battle to stay in Britain.

Euro judges deliver their long-awaited ruling on his appeal.

But the Government was urged to IGNORE the Strasbourg court if it backs Hamza — and hand him to America for trial immediately.

Hamza is wanted in the US on 11 terrorism charges.

But the Egyptian-born radical and five other extremists are claiming jail terms of up to 50 years in a “supermax” US prison would breach their human rights.

They say such sentences without parole constitute “inhuman or degrading treatment” — which would rule out extradition.

Last night Tory MPs finally lost patience and told Home Secretary Theresa May to defy the European Court of Human Rights if necessary and give Hamza the boot.

Ex-ministerial aide Stewart Jackson told The Sun: “The British people are at the end of their tether. Abu Hamza and others should be put on a plane and extradited to the US regardless of the court’s decision.”

Fellow Tory MP Chris Heaton-Harris added: “We should tell them to stick their judgment where political correctness doesn’t shine — and send Hamza to the US to receive justice.”

US authorities have described Hamza as a “terrorist facilitator with a global reach” and have been trying to get him extradited since 2004.

He faces charges related to taking 16 hostages in Yemen in 1998, promoting violent jihad in Afghanistan in 2001 and conspiring to set up a jihad training camp in Oregon.

There are fears of a repeat of the Abu Qatada deportation madness if Strasbourg rules in Hamza’s favour.

He is currently in Belmarsh high-security prison in Woolwich, South East London, after being jailed in 2006 for incitement to murder.

But he is eligible for parole and could be out in weeks — just before the Olympics — if the unelected Euro judges block extradition. Britain then has three months to appeal against the decidion.

Our judges may decide to FREE all six terror suspects on bail if the meantime. That is how al-Qaeda lynchpin Abu Qatada won his freedom in February.

Mrs May has been forced into protracted negotiations with Jordan, where Qatada is wanted.

She is trying to convince the Euro court that evidence against him won’t have been obtained by torture.

Cops and MI5 have had to mount expensive surveillance operations in the meantime — and could now be forced to do the same with Hamza.

In striking contrast, French authorities recently removed two Islamists considered a threat to national security, despite also signing the human rights convention.

And the Italian government deported a former Islamist prisoner to Tunisia, even though it contravened a Euro court ruling.

Mr Jackson said: “We should take a leaf out of the French book. The ultimate say should be with British judges.

“If it means ignoring the human rights court we should do that. I hope Theresa May takes that on board. It’s the people’s will.”

The scandal follows other human rights rulings that make a mockery of our fight to rid the country of foreign-born criminals.

The Sun has led calls to sling out Hamza — the former infamous hate preacher at Finsbury Park Mosque in London — since 2003.

The Home Office said: “We can confirm the European Court of Human Rights judgments in the cases of Abu Hamza and five others are due to be given on April 10. All have appealed against extradition to the US.”

t.newtondunn@the-sun.co.uk

13yrs bid to jail him



CALLS to jail Abu Hamza go back as far as 1999 when three British tourists were killed in Yemen.

The Muslim fanatic was held responsible after his vile rantings. Hook arrived in Britain in 1983 and developed extreme beliefs. In 1990 he returned to his homeland Egypt.

On returning in the 90s, he claimed he lost an eye and hand from battling jihad in Afghanistan. Hamza began preaching jihad at Finsbury Park, recruiting youngsters.

He was jailed for seven years in 2006 for soliciting murder and inciting racial hatred. But he was first arrested in 2004, when US extradition proceedings began. He appealed against extradition in 2007.

Now he is eligible for parole on the UK charges and is only locked up due to the US extradition bid.

Five more moaners



THE five other terror suspects held in the UK who are bleating to the European Court of Human Rights are:

Babar Ahmad: Accused by America of leading a “terrorism support cell”. He won a stay on his US extradition at the European court in June 2007.

Syed Ahsan: He is accused of supporting terrorists and helping Babar Ahmad. He was arrested in July 2006 — and his extradition ordered in June 2007.

Khalid Al Fawwaz: Faces charges over bombings of US Embassies in East Africa in 1998. Ordered to the US in 2008, but his extradition was halted the next year.

Adel Abdul Bary: Arrested for same alleged offences as Al Fawwaz. Got extradition orders in 2008. ECHR put a stay on extradition in December 2009.

Haroon Aswat: Charged with helping Hamza plan a terror camp in Oregon. Extradition to US ordered in March 2006. Euro judges put a stay on extradition in June 2007.

pages.headline: Hair Hitlers
pages.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: Brussels bans hairdressers from wearing jewellery over risk of disease
pages.byline: By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
HAIRDRESSERS could be banned from wearing high heels, jewellery and even watches under barmy new Brussels rules.

They would have to don “suitable clothes” and face a strict limit on the number of haircuts they can do each day.

And to prevent them suffering “emotional collapses”, bosses would be ordered to meticulously plan their working day so staff can have regular natters with each other.

The potty plan adds further fuel to The Sun’s Tear Up The Red Tape campaign against the bureaucracy strangling thousands of small businesses.

Government ministers immediately vowed to fight “tooth, nail and comb” against the scheme, which the National Hairdressing Federation estimate would cost them £3million.

Employment Minister Chris Grayling said: “This kind of stupidity has to stop.

“These stupid rules just cost jobs and right now we should be creating jobs, not killing them.”

The directives have been drawn up by EU Coiffure and UNI Europa Hair & Beauty — two organisations representing employers and workers across the union.

Brussels bureaucrats can reject them but in the past similar schemes have been nodded through.

One clause says: “Workers shall not wear jewellery as the skin underneath is prone to disease as a result of dampness or chemicals.”

Another adds: “Workers shall wear suitable clothes and, in particular, shoes with non-slip soles.”

Meanwhile employers are urged to “ensure a careful preparation of work, an appropriate planning of working time and work organisation aiming at preventing emotional collapses”.

Britain’s small businesses complain red tape adds a whopping £80billion a year to their running costs.

If just a tenth were axed, enough cash would be saved to create up to 250,000 jobs.

pages.subdeck: DOWNER ... Mario Balotelli has apologised
pages.headline: Balotelli says sorry
pages.teaser: ITALIAN could now get one more chance to save his Manchester City career
pages.byline: By MARTIN BLACKBURN and ANDREW DILLON
pages.articlebody:
MARIO BALOTELLI last night said sorry to boss Roberto Mancini — and could now get one more chance to save his Manchester City career.

The controversial Italian issued a grovelling apology after his red card in Sunday’s 1-0 defeat at Arsenal left City’s title hopes hanging by a thread.

Balotelli, 21, said: “I’m really sorry for what happened and for the disappointment I’ve caused Man City, particularly Roberto Mancini for whom I have a great respect and whom I love.

“As for my future, we will see at the end of the season. I’ll talk with the club and we will see.”

Mancini insisted the ex-Inter Milan striker would not play again this season and would “probably” be sold in the summer.

But FA insiders have indicated Balotelli may avoid a further three-match ban for his unpunished knee-high tackle on Arsenal midfielder Alex Song.

That means he will be available for the crunch Manchester derby at the Etihad on April 30, along with the final two matches.

And that would be the lifeline he needs to show his fellow Italian he is worth another season in England’s top flight.

Balotelli’s agent Mino Raiola said last night: “I heard Roberto and can guarantee the intention is not to sell Mario.

“Maybe Roberto said those things because a defeat is hard to swallow. But I think there was a misunderstanding.”

pages.headline: My fling with £3m jackpot bus driver

pages.byline: By RYAN SABEY and RACHEL DALE
pages.articlebody:
A BUS driver who won £3.1million on EuroMillions cheated on his partner with a passenger — after begging her for sex on the number six.

David Mead, 54, had a steamy three-month fling with Alison Sutton, 26, before scooping the windfall.

Lover Alison claims the dad of four even asked her to have kinky romps on his bus.

David, of Corby, Northants, who was part of a 12-strong depot syndicate that won £38million last month, repeatedly told Alison she had “perfect breasts” and sent flirty texts.

Alison said: “Whenever I went into Corby I would have to get on David’s bus.

“He would tell me to make sure I wore a low cut top so that he could check my boobs out in his mirror, which I did.

“Every time we pulled up at a bus stop I would feel his eyes on me. Then he would send me a text message saying how sexy I looked.

“He would message me saying things like: ‘I want to chuck everyone off this bus so I can drive you somewhere quiet to have sex.’

“I wouldn’t agree because I knew that there were cameras on the bus and the control centre would be able to see us. But it didn’t stop him trying.”

The relationship with Alison took place last summer behind the back of David’s partner Linda. Alison had split from her husband Wayne.

The pair kept the relationship quiet by meeting at David’s home and spending the day in bed together while his partner was at work.

But after his mega-bucks win, David was keen to portray himself as a family man. Following the windfall his brother Graham spoke about how David wanted to “buy a new car and look after his family”.

But Alison — who has moved away from the area to St Neots, Cambridgeshire — said: “There were pictures of David and Linda all over the house. He didn’t bother to hide them. I knew about her anyway.

“I wasn’t proud of what we were doing but I felt really alone at the time because I had just separated from my husband. David gave me a lot of attention and made me feel special.

“He told me he loved everything about my body, he loved curves.

“We spent whole days in the bed he shared with Linda while she was out. He thought I was great because I would use sex toys with him.”

The pair met through Alison’s ex-husband who worked at the same bus depot as David. When The Sun approached David at his home in Corby he said that the couple had sex just once.

He also claimed he had told Linda about the affair, saying their relationship was “open” and she had forgiven him.

A DALEK pensioned off years ago to The Sun newsroom was last night poised to battle Doctor Who again — after an SOS from the BBC.

Producers of the hit sci-fi show issued a worldwide appeal to borrow back the flogged-off aliens because they do not have enough for the next series.

Recent episodes have seen armies of the Doctor’s arch-enemies created using special effects — but this time around “real” Daleks are needed for an epic battle to exterminate latest Time Lord Matt Smith.

Executive producer Caroline Skinner confirmed yesterday: “We’re collecting every Dalek known to man. It’s going to be great.”

Among the retirees already recruited is one called Russell T Dalek — whose proud owner is the show’s former supremo Russell T Davies.

Last night The Sun’s was on standby to join them — after spending the past six years harmlessly confronting visitors to our Wapping HQ.

Our gold-coloured Dalek last came face to face with the Doctor when he was played by Jon Pertwee.

That was way back in a 1972 adventure called Day Of The Daleks. We acquired him in 2004 amid fears the famous aliens would not be appearing when the BBC decided to resurrect Doctor Who after a nine-year gap. That was because of a row with the family of Dalek creator Terry Nation.

Our space monster showed his mettle by fronting The Sun’s successful “Bring Back The Daleks” crusade — attacking BBC Television Centre and swooping on the film set in Cardiff.

Last night the latest Doctor Who supremo Steven Moffat said: “We’d like to assure The Sun we take very good care of all our Daleks and see no harm comes to them during production.”

He added: “Except for the ones the Doctor blows up, of course.”

ZIMBABWEAN tyrant Robert Mugabe is fighting for life in a Singapore hospital, it was reported last night.

The 88-year-old is said to be having intensive treatment for a mystery illness. It follows reports he is to hand power to feared Defence Minister Emmerson Mnangagwa.

Mugabe was flown to Singapore last week after collapsing at home. It was claimed he had gone to see his daughter enrol at university, which does not start until September.

Family members joined him on Saturday and, on Sunday, the Zimbabwe government postponed a cabinet meeting due to be held yesterday.

Officials say he will be home tomorrow following his “Easter holidays”.

A British-based analyst said: “Mugabe’s health impacts on Zimbabwe’s political landscape. Everything revolves around his health and his age.”

A leaked 2008 US diplomatic cable suggested he has prostate cancer.

nibs.teaser: SHEILA Lee crashed into a family’s car on way to prison — killing the dad and teen son
nibs.byline: By ROBIN PERRIE and ANDREW PARKER
nibs.articlebody:
A WOMAN pensioner who crashed into a family’s car — killing the dad and teenage son — was on the way to visit her paedophile husband in prison.

Sheila Lee, 70, veered across the carriageway and hit a VW Golf driven by Derek Sarkar, 46.

He and son Ethan, 14, died instantly. Sheila was also killed. Derek’s wife Karen and daughter Abbie are still in hospital.

Sheila was driving to see husband Barry, 67, at Doncaster jail, where he is serving seven years after abusing two generations of the same family over two decades.

He assaulted one girl repeatedly when she was between ten and 17.

A decade later he preyed on her daughter. After his trial in December police described him as “a vile and heartless monster”.

Sheila’s Volvo hit the Sarkars’ car at Saturday lunchtime near East Cowick, East Yorks.

Her daughter, driving a car behind, had also been heading to the prison and came across the wreckage minutes after the smash.

Karen, 43, and Abbie, nine, from Birmingham, were airlifted to hospital in Leeds. They were initially critically ill but had made a slight improvement by yesterday.

Ethan’s best friend Connor Meredith, 14, was in contact with him on BlackBerry messenger when the crash took place.

He said: “I was speaking to him and then he just didn’t reply. I found out later what had happened. I thought the world of him. I am devastated.”

Sheila’s neighbour Lawrence Graves, 75, said in Wigginton, York: “She was devastated when Barry was sent to prison but she tried her best to get on with things.”

nibs.teaser: ENGAGED Jason Roberts had told benefits officials that he was single and living alone
nibs.articlebody:
A BENEFIT cheat was caught after updating his Facebook status from single to engaged.

Jason Roberts, 42, had told benefits officials he was single and living alone.

But investigators spotted the Facebook change and found he was living with his girlfriend Gemma Dykins.

The telephone bill and television licence at his home were both in the name of Dykins and her employers had held painter Roberts’ address as her address since October 2009.

He claimed he was just friends with Dykins before later admitting he was lying.

Roberts used the ruse to claim £7,580 in jobseekers’ allowance, income support, housing benefit and council tax benefit.

Roberts, of Mold, North Wales, admitted failing to notify a change of circumstances between October 2009 and June last year.

He was given a 12-month community order with 240 hours’ unpaid work and ordered to pay £240 costs.

Defence lawyer Huw Roberts told Flintshire magistrates the dad of three was remorseful.

He had a prison record but no convictions for seven years and no dishonesty raps for 15.

He added that Roberts had changed his life and had become the prime carer for his children after his ex-wife was jailed over an armed robbery.

pages.headline: Manorexia toll trebles in 10yrs
pages.teaser: SOARING numbers of UK males are suffering from life-threatening eating disorders
pages.byline: By ANTHONY FRANCE and EMMA LITTLE
pages.articlebody:
SOARING numbers of UK males are suffering from life-threatening eating disorders, a Sun investigation has revealed.

We found young lads are at particular risk from conditions such as anorexia and bulimia, amid increasing pressure on them to look slim.

Hospital admissions for sufferers aged under 18 have TREBLED in a decade, according to NHS figures released after a freedom of information request.

They show 78 under-14 boys with eating disorders were admitted to hospital in England last year — compared with 24 in 2001.

And 39 lads aged 15-18 were treated in 2011, compared with 15 in 2001.

Overall, 228 males were admitted last year — more than double the 108 in 2001. But the full extent of the problem is far greater.

The figures do not account for GP consultations or those seeking help in private clinics.

And vast numbers endure the dangerous disorders in silence.

It is now estimated that 20 per cent of the 1.6million people with eating disorders in the UK are male.

Yet authorities still place a far higher emphasis on identifying female sufferers.

Last year we revealed that boys as young as ten were falling victim to bulimia.

Doctors warned then that the true problem was “hidden” as many boys did not tell anyone about their illness.

Experts say growing scrutiny of male bodies in the media, fashion trends like skinny-fit jeans, and the need to post photos on social networking sites have helped fuel the rise in eating disorders.

The condition can also be caused by stress brought on by events such as exams or relationship problems.

Sufferers often develop crushingly low self-esteem and become withdrawn.

But experts say the conditions are successfully treatable — particularly when they are identified in the early stages.

  • MOST popular diets don’t work — while non-prescription weight-loss pills and diet foods and products just as useless, according to a US study. Eating less fat, exercising more and using prescribed diet drugs were found to be far more effective.

    a.france@the-sun.co.uk

    myView

    By SAM THOMAS, Founder of the charity MGEDT

    THERE is still a lot of stigma attached to eating disorders.

    Stereotypical assumptions can make it more difficult for male sufferers to seek help.

    They may not be able to recognise symptoms easily and GPs may also be less aware of the signs. Worries over money, relationships, self-image and identity are all causes.

    Men may feel more pressure due to a growing trend focusing on the ideal body image.

    While negative body image alone is not responsible for causing eating disorders, it magnifies insecurities and reinforces low feelings of self-worth.

    Eating disorders have the highest mortality rate of any mental health condition. It is vital that sufferers seek treatment early on.

A BATTALION of 800 union agitators are trousering taxpayers’ cash to stir up classroom strikes.

The NUT, NASUWT and ATL officials cost the state £13million a year.

At Easter conferences, the first two unions voted for a fresh wave of school walkouts this year. A repeat of the 2011 one-day strikes over public sector pension reform will cause mayhem for parents.

But Freedom of Information requests seen by The Sun reveal taxpayers fund 633 people at 120 local authorities who spend some or all of their time on duty for one of the three big teaching unions.

If all 152 councils had responded, the number would top 800. Almost half, around 360, work full-time on union duty.

Tory MP Gavin Williamson said: “Taxpayers will already be angry at the prospect of more unjustified industrial action. It will rub salt in the wounds to learn that they are bankrolling union officials who are orchestrating these strikes.”

NUT bosses called for a new campaign of “mass resistance” against plans to vary pay by region. Ministers want to even up gaps between public and private sector pay.

ARGENTINA is refusing to pay a long-standing £45million debt to Britain for weaponry used to attack the Falklands.

It emerged that Buenos Aires still owes us the sum spent on ships and helicopters in 1979 — three years before the war.

It is now the responsibility of UK Export Finance, an offshoot of Vince Cable’s department, to deal with the debt.

There is pressure on him to follow his party’s line on handing debt to dictators.

A 2010 paper says it is Lib Dem policy to cancel debt “recklessly given to dictators known not to be committed to spend the loans on development”.

But a business department spokesman said the Government has “no plans” to offer debt forgiveness.

The Jubilee Debt Campaign blasted the loan to the Argentinian military junta as “illegitimate and odious”.

Director Nick Dearden called on the Government to “stop subsidising war”.

Last week marked the 30th anniversary of the Falklands war.

pages.articlebody:
FACEBOOK is to splash out $1billion to buy a popular photo-sharing smartphone app.

Instagram allows users to add filters and effects to pictures taken on their phones before they share them with others.

They make the photos look like they have been taken on retro cameras such as Polaroids.

The free app was only launched in October 2010 but already has 30million iPhone and Android phone users.

The $1billion (£629million) purchase — Facebook’s biggest ever — was a surprise to industry-watchers.

It comes as the social networking site prepares to offer shares to the general public.

Facebook said it plans to keep Instagram as a separate brand, rather than integrate it into its main website.

Its founder Mark Zuckerberg said: “We think the fact that Instagram is connected to other services beyond Facebook is an important part of the experience.”

A HARD-working dad of 12 who blasted benefits spongers for failing to support their kids has emigrated — because he thinks Britain’s future is so bleak.

Dave Jones and wife Jackie have taken their brood to Australia because he reckons they will have better prospects Down Under.

Dave, 42, said: “I have to do the best for my kids and I feel the opportunities I want for them will not be there in the UK.”

He told The Sun in August 2010 how he raised his family on the £38,000 a year he made from night shifts at a paper mill.

He spoke out after we revealed a jobless Bristol couple were pocketing £30,000 a year in benefits to raise their 12 kids.

Dave said then: “It makes our blood boil. I want people to realise that big families are not all the same.”

He and Jackie, 43, from Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, had 11 youngsters at the time.

Now they have paid £8,000 to fly the children, aged three to 18, and latest arrival Lily, four months, to Brisbane. Dave said: “We asked who wanted to go and they all did.”

pages.headline: Mum blamed party noise on a ghost
pages.teaser: WOMAN told neighbours who complained about loud music that a poltergeist was to blame
pages.articlebody:
A MUM evicted over her late-night parties claims the noise was caused by a GHOST.

Leanne Fennell, 20, told locals who complained about loud music and beer cans left in her garden that a poltergeist turned the music on while she was in bed.

But she said online: "I love to party." She also boasted that her friends could not "keep up" with her.

She has now been forced to leave her council home in Hull, East Yorks, after the council took her to court for ignoring a noise abatement order.

One neighbour, who did not wish to be named, said: “She told us a poltergeist would keep switching the music on really loud when she was in bed.”

“Some of the neighbours had a terrible time.

“There were always bottles and bottles of wine and cider just chucked in the garden.

“She had at least four huge bonfires to burn some of the rubbish that was in there.

“Some people complained and then she was warned by the council, but she didn’t listen.

“Eventually, it went too far and we’d had enough.”

Locals had to put up with night after night of loud parties, which did not finish until the early hours of the morning.

Another neighbour said: “She was playing loud music at all hours. We reported her loads of times.

“It is nice to have some peace and quiet around here now she has gone.”

On her Facebook page, Fennell wrote: “First and most of all I’m a proud mam to a beautiful little girl. I’m not fussy ... but a girl should try look her best 24/7.

“I also sin but I’m not the devil, so with me what you see is what you get.

"I love to party with my mates, well, the ones who can keep up with me that is.”

Hull Magistrates' Court found Fennell guilty of four breaches of the noise abatement notice, and another requiring her to remove rubbish from the garden.

She was ordered to pay fines of £370 and costs of £500 to Hull City Council.

pages.headline: Machete raiders tie up pregnant mum in front of her three-year-old son
pages.teaser: THREE men ransack rural home and tell boy, 3, they are' just playing a game'
pages.articlebody:
ARMED raiders carrying a machete and baseball bat tied a pregnant woman to a chair and ransacked her home in front of her three-year-old son.

Terrified Victoria Ratheram, 28, was bound in the nursery of her £200,000 house.

Victoria, who is eight months pregnant, has told how the three men attempted to calm her son by telling him they were “just playing a game”.

The robbers struck in broad daylight after her husband James, 32, had gone to work.

Victoria, from Wollerton, Shrops, said: “I was about to go out when three men walked through the front door with a machete and what looked like an old-style police truncheon.

“They were very scary and it was very traumatic.

“I am eight months pregnant. I had my three-year-old with me and they tied me to a kitchen chair in the nursery we have prepared for my new son.

“Luckily my son is not too traumatised by it, the men told him it was just a game.”

Victoria was finally freed when a neighbour’s daughter called round to use the phone.

She does not feel safe in her own home now but has vowed to remain.

Victoria added: “I will not let these men make me leave my house. I have no intention of letting these people make me move.

“It is my home, not theirs.”

Until she was freed she had no idea two other people had been victims in a separate raid on Thursday.

The gang also preyed on a woman and her teenage son who needed an operation after having his hand cut.

The raiders escaped in a stolen Land Rover Discovery.

Detective Inspector Pete Brophy, who is leading the investigation for West Mercia Police, said: “I am still appealing for witnesses who spotted a silver saloon car in the village on Thursday from about 6am.”

Dad-of-two Phil Sherriff, 37, was rushed to hospital with a severe neck wound but could not be saved.

Telecom worker Phil’s relatives, including photographer wife Jane, paid tribute to him in a statement today, saying: “Phil was the most genuine, likeable and generous man you could ever hope to meet.

“He was a perfect husband, son and father to our daughter, aged eight, and son, aged five.

"His death is completely and utterly devastating.”

Singer Jessie expressed her shock at the attack which erupted moments after she had performed at a star-studded BlackBerry Messenger (BBM) party at Pulse nightclub in Southwark, London last week.

The Voice judge told of her sadness after Phil lost his fight for life.

She wrote: “I am lost for words.

“All I can say is my thoughts, love and respects are with the family and children of the man who attended the blackberry gig last week who sadly lost his life this morning <3 So sad.”

Mr Sherriff, from Preston, Lancs was rushed to hospital after being stabbed in the early hours of Wednesday but died in hospital yesterday.

A post-mortem confirmed he died from a stab wound to the neck.

Before Mr Sherriff’s death, company director Ashley Charles, 25, of Leicester, appeared at Camberwell Green Magistrates’ Court charged with attempted murder.

He was remanded in custody to appear at Inner London Crown Court on Friday April 20.

The party was attended by several celebrities including stars of The Only Way Is Essex, as well as rappers Chipmunk and Wretch 32 who performed a set.

pages.headline: Easter dank holiday a washout
pages.teaser: BUT it will have no effect on drought or hosepipe bans, experts warn
pages.articlebody:
MILLIONS of Brits will return to work today after a bleak Bank Holiday washout.

Many holidaymakers woke up to grey skies today as the weekend’s gloomy weather took a turn for the worse.

In Wales, more than two inches of rain fell in ten hours, while the south west and south east of England were also soaked by squalls.

Daytrippers in Bournemouth, Dorset, huddled under umbrellas as downpours hit.

Mum-of-two Sandra Brook, 42, sighed: “It’s another bank holiday washout, but I suppose it’s about time we had some rain.”

Cross-Channel ferries were buffeted by 50mph winds while temperatures in the east also plunged to single figures, making it one of the chilliest Easters on record.

The coldest ever was in 1964 at just 6°C (42°F).

And in Scotland snow showers were expected for the week ahead.

Yet despite the dire forecast, experts warned it would have NO impact on the current drought or see hosepipe bans lifted.

Meanwhile, the Met Office said mercury levels could dip to as low as -5°C (23°F) in the Midlands by Friday.

Forecaster George Goodfellow said: “It was a dull, grey and wet Bank Holiday and anyone going outdoors would have needed a coat.

“Most places had rain, with two inches on higher ground in Wales, over an inch in England’s south-west and lower amounts elsewhere.

“Every little helps drought areas — but there’s not sustained rain ahead.”

He added: “It will feel cold this week, with a mix of sunshine and showers, wintry over northern hills — and Scotland forecast snow at lower levels over the weekend.”

A FRANTIC bid to rescue nine miners trapped 820ft underground has been delayed after further sections of roof collapsed.

Rescuers at the unlicensed gold and copper mine may not reach the stricken team for a further three days.

The workers have been trapped in southern Peru since Thursday but have managed to communicate with officials and loved ones on the surface.

Rescue workers are chewing coca leaves in the belief it will help them tackle the mammoth task.

Agustin Jurado, one of the rescuers, said: “Coca gives us strengths to face the forces of the mountain.

“These hills emit dangerous gases, and coca defends us from them."

Coca leaves are used to make cocaine.

The disaster is bound to bring back memories of the 33 men trapped underground in Chile for 69 days in 2010. All miraculously survived.

The men stuck in the Cabeza de Negro mine are 22 to 59 and include a father and son.

They became trapped in a horizontal tunnel when a shaft collapsed.

None are injured and they remain together. They are being supplied with oxygen, water and soup through a metal tube that they also use to communicate with rescue workers.

Relatives are staying at a makeshift camp with cops, firefighters and other miners.

Some of the miners are suffering from anxiety.

Jacinto Pariona begged: “We are depressed. Please, get us out of here.”

Workers were using buckets to remove the debris obstructing the shaft before pushing it out of the mine in a small mining car.

Cabeza de Negro is an unlicensed mine that was abandoned more than two decades ago by its owners but continues to be exploited.

pages.headline: Give Abu Hamza the boot
pages.teaser: AFTER nine-year fight human rights court says US can't have radical cleric
pages.articlebody:
HUMAN rights judges have ruled that hook-handed hate preacher Abu Hamza should be extradited to the US on terror charges.

A nine-year fight to ship Hamza, 53, to the US came to a head this morning when the fanatical hook-handed Muslim cleric and four other terrorist suspects learned they have lost their legal battle to stay in Britain.

Egyptian-born Hamza is wanted in the US on 11 terrorism charges and today the European Court of Human Rights ruled that his extradition along with four others is lawful.

Judges said that Hamza, Syed Ahsan, Khalid Al Fawwaz, Adel Abdul Bary and Babar Ahmad would not be subject to “ill-treatment” in America.

The extremists had claimed that they face jail terms of up to 50 years in a "supermax" US prison which would breach their human rights.

The court adjourned its decision on Haroon Rashid Aswat pending consideration of further complaints lodged by him.

US authorities have described Hamza as a “terrorist facilitator with a global reach” and have been trying to get him extradited since 2004.

He faces charges related to taking 16 hostages in Yemen in 1998, promoting violent jihad in Afghanistan in 2001 and conspiring to set up a jihad training camp in Oregon.

There had been fears of a repeat of the Abu Qatada deportation madness if Strasbourg ruled in Hamza’s favour.

He is currently in Belmarsh high-security prison in Woolwich, South East London, after being jailed in 2006 for incitement to murder.

The Sun has led calls to sling out Hamza — the former infamous hate preacher at Finsbury Park Mosque in London — since 2003.

The Home Office said: “We can confirm the European Court of Human Rights judgments in the cases of Abu Hamza and five others are due to be given on April 10. All have appealed against extradition to the US.”

t.newtondunn@the-sun.co.uk

13yrs bid to jail him



CALLS to jail Abu Hamza go back as far as 1999 when three British tourists were killed in Yemen.

The Muslim fanatic was held responsible after his vile rantings. Hook arrived in Britain in 1983 and developed extreme beliefs. In 1990 he returned to his homeland Egypt.

On returning in the 90s, he claimed he lost an eye and hand from battling jihad in Afghanistan. Hamza began preaching jihad at Finsbury Park, recruiting youngsters.

He was jailed for seven years in 2006 for soliciting murder and inciting racial hatred. But he was first arrested in 2004, when US extradition proceedings began. He appealed against extradition in 2007.

Now he is eligible for parole on the UK charges and is only locked up due to the US extradition bid.

Five more moaners



THE five other terror suspects held in the UK who are bleating to the European Court of Human Rights are:

Babar Ahmad: Accused by America of leading a “terrorism support cell”. He won a stay on his US extradition at the European court in June 2007.

Syed Ahsan: He is accused of supporting terrorists and helping Babar Ahmad. He was arrested in July 2006 — and his extradition ordered in June 2007.

Khalid Al Fawwaz: Faces charges over bombings of US Embassies in East Africa in 1998. Ordered to the US in 2008, but his extradition was halted the next year.

Adel Abdul Bary: Arrested for same alleged offences as Al Fawwaz. Got extradition orders in 2008. ECHR put a stay on extradition in December 2009.

Haroon Aswat: Charged with helping Hamza plan a terror camp in Oregon. Extradition to US ordered in March 2006. Euro judges put a stay on extradition in June 2007.

Labour’s surrender on 10 per cent extra cider duty is a triumph for David Cameron.

The Tories also blocked Labour’s planned broadband tax.

Not a bad start as the Tories were clear winners on Day One of the election campaign.

In the Commons, Mr Cameron exposed Gordon Brown’s weasel words over Labour’s jobs tax.

Mr Brown says the business world has been deceived by the Tories into thinking that Labour’s National Insurance tax rise will cost jobs.

Business leaders say Mr Brown is patronising, “economically illiterate” and insults their intelligence.

Almost seventy of Britain’s biggest employers — including one of Mr Brown’s own advisers — say the Tories are RIGHT.

The Sun agrees. Making firms pay more in tax for every person hired means bosses take on fewer workers.

Only in the warped world of Gordon Brown does raising National Insurance help unemployment.

The fed-up business community has washed its hands of union-run Labour.

Employers think that there will be more REAL jobs under the Tories.

Exactly what the country needs to hear.

Blaze heroes

FIREMEN didn’t hesitate when they arrived at a blazing block of high-rise flats.

They plunged straight in — and two tragically lost their lives.

The Sun pays tribute to Hampshire fire heroes James Shears and Alan Bannon.

The brave men and women of our emergency services are very special.

When it comes to the crunch, they lay their lives on the line for us.

We are very lucky. We should be grateful and never forget their sacrifice.

Brave champ

TENNIS ace Martina Navratilova faces another tough challenge.

The legendary champ is diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 53.

Not even a superfit athlete like Martina is safe from a cancer that affects women indiscriminately.

Many Sun readers will have a relative or friend who has been struck down.

Cancer survival rates in Britain have improved over the years. But they lag behind much of Europe and America, where Martina is optimistic about her prospects.

Yes, times are tough. But our next Government must do much more to improve our record on survival rates for breast and other cancers.

Brave Martina, who never gave up on court, will not give up on this fight either.

The council’s Labour leader Tony Newman called it a “jolly” and said: “This sends out the wrong message.”

pages.teaser: CORPSE blimey! Horror fans are flocking to an old shopping mall to hunt creepy creatures
pages.articlebody:
CORPSE blimey! Horror fans are flocking to an old shopping mall to hunt ZOMBIES — like in cult movie Dawn Of The Dead.

It’s the latest role-playing craze and I joined the shootout in the twilight zone of Reading.

Like in a shoot-’em-up video game, 15 of us tiptoed in the dark with glow sticks strapped to our bullet-proof vests. Then a scream sparks panic.

Armed with pump-action shotguns — which fire plastic bullets — and coming face-to-face with one of the creatures is horrifying, actors or not.

I unleash a flurry of bullets into the three walking corpses, sending them flying on to their backs.

From then on the four-hour hunt races past in an adrenaline-fuelled blur of blood-spattered walls and reanimated corpses.

Being chased through a disused children’s play area — ball pit and all — is an eerie experience.

While more Shaun Of The Dead than Dawn Of The Dead, for £119 it is a bloody great day out.

pages.headline: Olympic fury as 84% of gifts made abroad
pages.teaser: JUST one in six Olympics gifts are made in Britain, a Sun investigation has found
pages.articlebody:
JUST one in six official souvenirs for the Olympics are made in Britain, a Sun investigation has found.

Out of nearly 900 items being sold on the London 2012 website, a measly 138 are produced in the UK.

We discovered a total of 717 gifts (84 per cent) are made abroad — findings that risked fury among snubbed British firms.

Olympic mascots Wenlock, Mandeville and Pride the Lion are among 627 items made in China.

The country also produced models of London buses and taxis emblazoned with the Union Jack.

T-shirts featuring landmarks from the capital are made in Pakistan, Team GB gym bags in Vietnam and Union Jack photo frames in Poland.

When London was awarded the Olympics, manufacturing and textiles industries were promised a huge boost.

Instead the Games committee is hoping to pocket £1BILLION from sales — and UK firms look set to miss out.

Birmingham-based Vaughtons, which made medals for the 1908 London Games, lost out to a Chinese firm for a contract to make lapel badges.

Sales director Nick Hobbis said: “We couldn’t believe it. Normally it is the host country that makes the bulk of the goods.

“The amount of badges being made could have been shared out among a string of British firms.”

John Walker of the Federation of Small Businesses called it “very disappointing”.

But a London 2012 spokesman insisted: “In the licensing and manufacturing industry, many products supplied and sold by UK firms are made overseas.”

David and Victoria are in for some serious earache as their kids are forming a band.

Brooklyn, who has been repeatedly strumming The Beatles’ Here Comes The Sun, plays guitar while Romeo is on drums.

Cruz, who is also mad on ballet, is the Bez of the group because he breakdances along to their efforts.

Victoria said: “As they go to bed the boys break into a chorus of Walk Like A Man. It’s their favourite song from the Jersey Boys musical. Cruz is very good at breakdancing as well. He spins on his head. And he is doing ballet — inspired by the fact that, ‘His cousin is very lucky because he gets to lift up girls’.”

Even though all three aren’t afraid of the mic, they’re missing a lead vocalist.

Perhaps Harper Seven could plug the gap in a few years.

Posh admitted: “I’d love to say they get the musical stuff from me, but they don’t.

“But they do have good fashion sense. I like to think that they have got that from me.” The Beckhams’ mansion must be like a madhouse.

If it’s not instruments lying around, it’s skateboards.

David and Victoria have admitted they often let the boys skate in the entrance hall because it’s safer.

Maybe Brooklyn, Romeo and Cruz could join forces with Gordon Ramsay’s musical youngsters.

Posh and Becks and their clan spent Easter weekend in California with the chef — whose nippers also have formed their own group.

Gordon said: “Tilly’s on the drums, Holly and Megan are on the piano and Jack’s on the guitar.

“It all started when they got obsessed with The X Factor.”

pages.headline: Lindsay Lohan accused of club bust-up
pages.teaser: WOMAN files battery complaint against the actress, claiming she shoved her at a nightspot in LA
pages.articlebody:
LINDSAY Lohan is in trouble with the law yet again.

The actress has been accused of shoving a woman at a Hollywood nightclub.

The alleged incident comes just days after LiLo finally got her freedom back when an LA judge ended her probation for drink-driving in 2007.

Now a female reveller has filed a battery complaint against the Mean Girls star, claiming Lohan assaulted her last week.

Los Angeles County Sheriff's official Sergeant Chris Bowman said: "It's just an allegation. It's been received by our detectives."

Lohan’s publicist has questioned why the alleged victim waited until Saturday to file a complaint.

Steve Honig said: "You have to wonder about someone who calls the media before the police."

Last month, Superior Court Judge Stephanie Sautner told Lohan she will no longer need to appear in court or report to a probation officer.

Judge Sautner praised the actress for the progress she has made and the star thanked her for her patience.

However, she is still on informal probation for stealing a £1,570 necklace from a boutique in Venice Beach, LA, last year.

Lohan has suffered a turbulent time since she the DUI arrests — she was in and out of rehab and prison for much of 2010.

But she has largely steered clear of trouble over the past year and there are signs of a comeback into films as well.

Having guest-hosted Saturday Night Live, Lohan is due to make a cameo in hit show Glee. She is also set to star as the late Elizabeth Taylor in a TV movie.

CHRISTINE Bleakley has angrily denied claims that she and fiancé Frank Lampard tried to bribe other couples to give up their wedding venues.

The pair, both 33, are said to have offered fortunes to two brides and grooms to rearrange their big days so the celebs can grab the booking date.

Dancing On Ice host Christine — set to wed the Chelsea ace this summer — raged: “I’d never in a million years ask someone to move a wedding.

“Stuff like that makes you out to be a horrible person.”

Newspapers in Ireland have reported claims that mega-rich Frank gave a couple £100,000 to switch their day at Galgorm Manor hotel in Co Antrim, near Christine’s family home.

He is also said to have offered to pay off another pair’s mortgage if they cancelled their wedding at Dromoland Castle Hotel, Co Clare.

Christine said: “One hotel even put out a story that I’d paid for an Italian restaurant to be opened in their venue because I wanted that food. I’d never get married there!”

A source close to her added: “All these tales are just an urban myth. The same rumours circulated when David and Victoria Beckham announced they were to wed.”

Christine insists she has no “concrete plans” for her day.

She said: “I honestly don't care whether the napkins match the colour of the bridesmaids’ dresses. I just want a low-key, relaxed day surrounded by the people I love.”

Christine also revealed she waited a year to meet Frank’s daughters Luna, six, and Isla, four, by his ex Elen Rivas.

She said: “I’ve tried to do it right and I think the dividends are paying off.”

pages.teaser: THE VOICE toff has already had a stab at the big time, even releasing an ALBUM
pages.articlebody:
THE VOICE toff Bo Bruce has already had a stab at the big time, even releasing an ALBUM, TV Biz can reveal.

And the former public schoolgirl got to the semi-final of ANOTHER telly singing contest on Channel 4.

The upper crust star, who has landed a spot on Danny O’Donoghue’s team — has made much of her wayward past of drugs and booze addiction, as well as battles with her family.

She wants to be seen as a normal girl despite being the daughter of an earl, whose real name is Lady Catherine Brudenell-Bruce.

But despite coming clean about some of her past she has so far neglected to discuss her music industry links.

We can reveal that she originally changed her name to Bo Bruce to enter the Orange Unsigned Act show on C4 in 2008. She made it to the semi-final round and caught the eyes of record label bosses.

She reportedly signed a deal with BMG, the record group that used to be linked to Simon Cowell through Sony Music.

She released a five-track EP last year — still available on sites such as Amazon.

But last night a BBC spokesman said Bo’s CD would NOT disqualify her from the contest as she was no longer signed to a label.

We told yesterday how Bo was desperate to change people’s perception of her as a privileged, blue-blooded aristocrat.

She said: “Although I was born into a privileged family, that spoon in my mouth was pretty rusty and not very silver. I don’t live in Downton Abbey, this is the 21st Century. I work in a pub and struggle to pay my electricity bills just like everyone else.”

She is one of several wannabes on The Voice who have already had brushes with fame.

Saturday night’s show also featured reggae artist Cassius Henry, who had a record deal and once appeared on Top Of The Pops.

But their repeated attempts to make it big aren’t impressing some music legends.

Former Jam frontman Paul Weller told the Radio Times that shows like The Voice and The X Factor were “Saturday-night viewing for the masses,” adding: “Would I be a judge? Would I hell. I’d be too embarrassed to be on those shows.”

Pianist and TV presenter Jools Holland, also interviewed by the magazine, added: “Music is not like a competition. It’s an art form.

“I would not knock the competition shows if that’s what people want to do.

“But there’s a difference between having it like a game show and having it as something that connects with your spirit and moves you... that’s what music’s supposed to be about.”

pages.headline: Gervais: Derek is just a nerd
pages.teaser: FUNNYMAN defends his new show, claiming it is not meant to be a jibe at people with learning disabilities
pages.articlebody:
RICKY GERVAIS has defended his new show, insisting it is not a jibe at people with learning disabilities.

The comic, who sparked a storm last year after a string of “mong” jokes, said his new Channel 4 programme, Derek, does not mock the mentally vulnerable.

Ricky said: “If I say I don’t mean him to be disabled, then that’s it.

“A fictional doctor can’t come along and prove me wrong.”

The comedy follows simpleton Derek Noakes, who works in a retirement home.

Comparing the character, who he plays, to other gormless screen roles, Ricky told disability rights campaigner Nicky Clark, who confronted him over the last scandal: “He’s better than me. He’s better than most people.

“He’s different. But then so are a lot of people. He’s not the smartest tool in the box but he’s cleverer than Father Dougal and not as different as Mr Bean.

“He’s based on those you meet who are on the margins of society. Nerds, loners, under-achievers.”

The show, which co-stars Ricky’s pal Karl Pilkington as Derek’s colleague Dougie, airs on Thursday at 10pm.

The judging panel will consist of Jongleurs founder and owner Maria Kempinska, Comedy Producer Jerry Palmer and iconic Hi-De-Hi actress Vicki Michelle.

Maria said: "It's great to be extending the 'comedy invite' to encourage a wider variety of acts. We want to show people that there is more to comedy than the straight stand-up that you see on the telly.

"And all of this to mark our brand new Jongleurs venue in London's Haymarket. It couldn't be better!"

Jerry Palmer, of 4D Productions, added: "We're just looking to find funny people. It's as simple as that. We want funny people. I simply can't say that enough - we want to find funny people!"

A PREENING Take Me Out romeo dubbed the most arrogant contestant ever is gunning for a second stab at fame – on The X Factor.

Damion Merry stunned viewers on the dating show by insulting nearly all the girls and forgetting his own date’s name.

He received death threats after the cringe-worthy appearance on the ITV1 programme in February.

Now he wants to put his shameful appearance — a YouTube sensation with 1.4million hits — behind him and make it big as a singer.

The 27-year-old tried out at the London auditions at the O2 Arena on Saturday after lining up with 11,000 fellow hopefuls.

He performed in front of the ITV show’s production staff, who pick out acts to audition later in front of the judges.

A source told TV Biz: “He turned up and was quite cocky, as though we were supposed to know who he was. But then it clicked — we did know who he was. He was the arrogant one from Take Me Out.

“To be fair he didn’t have the worst singing voice in the world, so we put him through.

“Now he might get to try out in front of the judges so we’ll leave it to Gary Barlow and the others to determine if he’s actually any good.”

Damion wasn’t the only familiar face to turn up to the tryouts on Saturday, which were hosted by Dermot O’Leary.

Oddball David Wilder, who on last year’s series described himself as the “greatest person” ever to be on the X Factor, also turned up.

pages.teaser: CLEAN-LIVING X Factor band on weight, boys and their mission to teach girls respect
pages.articlebody:
MOST girlbands love to pose in next to nothing, but Little Mix have vowed to keep their clothes ON — or risk a telling off at home.

The X Factor winners are on a mission to teach girls their age about “earning sexual respect”.

So the group — Perrie Edwards and Jade Thirlwall, both 18, and 20-year-olds Jesy Nelson and Leigh-Anne Pinnock — have a self-imposed ban on appearing in any sexy photoshoots.

And they insist they don’t have anything to put on display even if they wanted to.

Perrie, from South Shields, Tyne & Wear, said: “Not a chance, I don’t even have any sexy curves to show off — my chest is like flat pancakes.

“We’re only young as well. My mam would give us a slap if she saw me in my bra in a magazine.”

Jade, also from South Shields, added: “I think you have to earn your sexual respect. We’re not exactly at the stage where we could get away with doing something like that and have people concentrate on our music.

“Little Mix’s first single all naked? Can you imagine?”

In a world where the music channels are dominated by sexed-up stars gyrating in their underwear, Little Mix are a breath of fresh air.

Their dressing room is not hard to find. Hair straighteners sit on every surface, big boxes of make-up are piled high and overflowing girly suitcases are everywhere.

The only surprise is the totally demolished rider tray, strewn with empty crisp packets, cola bottles and biscuit wrappers — unheard of for other diet-obsessed girlbands.

For four young women in the spotlight, they have an extremely healthy attitude towards eating.

That goes especially for Jesy who, despite attracting nasty comments about her figure since first appearing on TV last year, is determined to stay curvy as a message to her female fans. Even though she has dropped a few pounds since the show finished, the singer from Romford, Essex, insists she has not tried to lose weight.

She said: “People are always commenting on how I look and it’s because I’m a girl. You never see men’s bodies being criticised in magazines.

“Once I came off the TV show everyone thought I was on a strict diet but I’d just stopped going to the ITV canteen every day, with fry-ups every morning and chips for lunch, so I lost quite a bit of weight. I’m not going to suddenly become skinny — we’re all different shapes and sizes in the band and people relate to us because we look normal.

“It’s one of the reasons we won the show.

“If I started to look like I’d lost two stone it would send out the wrong message.”

It’s surprising the girls find time to eat these days, since being formed for the show and bagging the prize they have barely had a minute spare. This time just a year ago between them they were waitressing, working as barmaids and finishing college courses.

Fast forward 12 months and they have a No1 single under their belts and are about to start work on a group autobiography.

And there’s no let-up any time soon.

The X Factor tour completed its final show on Friday night, so now the girls are focusing full-time on putting the finishing touches to their debut album.

With such hectic work schedules, it’s little surprise that three out of the four girls have decided against the distractions of having a boyfriend.

Only Jesy is currently in a relationship, after recently getting together with Jordan Banjo, a member of the BGT dance troupe Diversity.

Both Perrie and Jade have seen long-term relationships end since becoming famous. Jade split with her boyfriend of five years just two months ago after it became too difficult to juggle with her career.

And the girls have now sworn off boys for the time being.

Leigh-Anne, from High Wycombe, Bucks, said: “Each of us are the most important thing to us right now. We’re very career orientated. With all of this going on we don’t have time for boyfriends.

“The strangest thing recently is having guys at concerts who are interested in us.

“At the beginning it had been all girl fans, so we’re not very good with that kind of attention yet.

“Someone grabbed Jade’s arm at our concert the other night and shouted, ‘I want you!’ She just kind of screamed and ran on to the stage. We all burst out laughing.”

The girls are so close that although they have spent the past eight months in each other’s pockets 24 hours a day, the plan is to become neighbours.

They are scouring London for two apartments side by side. Jade said: “We’re living out of a suitcase. We each have ten suitcases that follow us around, which is just the worst thing — all I want to do is hang up my clothes.

“We are going to move to London permanently very soon and get two apartments right next to each other. Me and Perrie are going to share and so are Leigh-Anne and Jesy.

“If the four of us all lived together the place would be a total pigsty.”

Alongside permanently living out of suitcases, constantly performing in thick stage make-up is also something the girls will be glad to see the back of.

Each of them is struggling to control outbreaks of spots since starting The X Factor tour.

Leigh-Anne explained: “Because we wear such thick make-up on stage, when we sweat under the lights it makes our skin really bad. You have to try to eat healthily and get enough sleep, otherwise it can get out of control.

“I’m using antibiotics because otherwise I would actually have really bad skin. It should hopefully go back to normal now we’ve stopped performing all the time.”

Fortunately for the girls, if they have any questions about touring, boys or the hardships of fame, they have one of the most experienced young women in showbusiness just a phone call away.

Tulisa Contostavlos, who acted as the band’s mentor on the ITV competition, has been a constant in their lives since the cameras stopped rolling. And that is extremely unusual for a talent show judge.

Contestants of similar programmes have complained of being dropped as protégés after leaving a series. But Tulisa has a hands-on approach to her “little muffins”.

Even on the day of my interview, despite having to deal with the fallout of her embarrassing sex tape being leaked online, she finds time to check out the X Factor show and visit the band backstage.

Perrie said: “She’s really great, we’re always on the phone to her.

“Things have been difficult recently but she’s been such a trooper — she’s the most real person ever and I think her strength is why we won the show in the first place.

“We formed such a strong bond with her, she’s not a mentor any more, she’s a really good friend.”

The group have also bumped into X Factor judges Gary Barlow and Louis Walsh since the final.

Jade said: “It’s weird when you see them after the show because there isn’t that pressure any more. It’s like when you see a teacher after you’ve left school.”

But the thought of meeting one particular music mogul sent shivers down the girls’ spines — their label boss Simon Cowell. They met with the X Factor guru last month to discuss their music career.

Perrie said: “Meeting Simon was like waiting outside the principal’s office. We felt like naughty schoolgirls and were all so scared that we could hardly breathe.

“I don’t know why we thought Simon was going to be this monster. It was just amazing how normal he is.”

pages.headline: Justin Bieber joins One Direction
pages.teaser: EVERY teenage girl’s dream has come true after the Canadian pop titan promises to record with the 1D lads
pages.articlebody:
EVERY teenage girl’s dream came true last night when One Direction joined Justin Bieber in the studio.

There hasn’t been pop excitement like it since Duran Duran and Spandau Ballet bumped into each other in the hairdressers back in 1984.

One D — Liam Payne, Louis Tomlinson, Niall Horan, Harry Styles and Zayn Malik — have been busy rehearsing in New York for a huge performance on TV’s Saturday Night Live tomorrow.

Canadian chart topper Justin happened to be recording in the same studio and invited his British pals in for a listen.

Justin finished the chat by saying they should “hook up” again to work on new material.

Niall tweeted: “In the studio with our boy @justinbieber last night, it’s gonna sound great!”

Louis added: “It was just nice to spend some time with someone our own age. Everyone in the band thought he was a really nice guy.”

It sounds like a proper bromance — but that’s as far as it goes. Liam had to deny gay rumours in an interview this week.

He said: “Some people think we are genuinely in a relationship. I have been asked by lots of fans about this.

“Who is spreading the word? Whoever it is the fans are believing them.”

Zayn added: “People are writing that me and Harry are a couple. They have got cutaways of us looking at each other in videos with romantic music playing.”

They might have to knock back the invitation to Bieber’s next sleepover then.

He has sealed the deal on his first home — a £4million mansion.

He agreed the fee for the six-bed house in Calabasas, California, on Wednesday after knocking almost £1million off the asking price.

He’d do well on The Apprentice with haggling like that.

The 9,000 sq ft home in a gated community around 20 miles from Hollywood also features a cinema for romantic nights in.

He’s also looking to the future, with a huge wine cellar in the basement.

That’s a lot of fizzy pop to store up until he reaches the legal drinking age.

pages.subdeck: Change of direction ... Megan Fox says she enjoyed working on a comedy film
pages.headline: Comedy is refreshing
pages.teaser: MEGAN Fox says role in The Dictator is a refreshing change from playing ice maidens
pages.articlebody:
MEGAN FOX spent years building up her image as an ice-cold sex goddess, but now finally has the chance to laugh at herself — and she couldn’t be more relieved.

In Sacha Baron Cohen’s new comedy film the beauty plays a stuck-up hooker who gets into a huff when she is paid with rubies rather than diamonds.

The character fumes: “What am I, a Kardashian?”.

It is just a cameo, but being able to get laughs out of her rather humour-free image is a joy for the Hollywood beauty.

Megan, 25, says: “When I first started acting I was always playing the bitchy or mean girl, then I was playing these cool, robotic women.

“I was growing tired of playing those kinds of characters and reinforcing this stereotype of me and having to play up to that when I was doing interviews.

“Now I feel I can be myself again. It’s given me the chance to get away from that sexy, icy image that I’ve been stuck with.

“I think the public can relate to me more easily in these kinds of movies.”

The actress also loved working with Baron Cohen — who plays deluded “supreme leader” Admiral General Shabazz Aladeen in The Dictator.

She says: “I had a wonderful time. Sacha is very smart and funny. We had a great time working together.

“I think audiences are going to love the film.”

Megan adds: “I’m discovering that I enjoy the atmosphere of being part of those kinds of films.

“Doing comedies has been a great change of pace for me and I’m interested to see how audiences react to seeing me in these kinds of films.

“I’m really enjoying my work again and I feel a lot of good things are happening to me.”

Such a feeling has been a long time coming.

Megan admits that she never enjoyed the years she felt obliged to play up to the serious, sex-vixen image.

Although she had modelled and acted since she was 15, she was hurtled into the global limelight when she won the role as Shia LaBeouf’s action sidekick Mikaela in Transformers in 2007.

She admits: “I just didn’t know how to handle the attention or make that image work for me. I felt I was suddenly living a double life and I was expected to behave a certain way. I just couldn’t be like that.

“I have a hard time holding back what I really think. I don’t like the idea of censoring myself and not speaking my mind or being humorous when I’m doing interviews.

“I’ve paid the price for being very open about my feelings.”

Most spectacularly, her openness backfired when, in a magazine interview in 2009, she likened Tranformers director Michael Bay to Hitler.

She was immediately fired from the franchise by its executive producer, Steven Spielberg.

Then, to make matters worse, three anonymous crew members on the films then posted a letter online calling her “dumb as a rock” and slamming her behaviour on set.

When asked what she has learned from these kinds of lows, Megan says: “To not be so bold and outspoken when it comes to talking about certain things.

“I’m a passionate individual and sometimes when I have strong feelings about a subject I feel the need to express myself.

“But I’ve learnt that it’s better to hold back a bit, that the world doesn’t necessarily need or want to know what I think about some matters.

“I still believe in being very honest and speaking my mind. I think that’s a good quality even if sometimes it has gotten me into trouble.”

As well as the new comedy gig, Megan is also still modelling. She is the face of Armani and also regularly tops lists of the world’s hottest women.

But Megan reckons her red-blooded male fans have the wrong idea about her two best features.

She says with a grin: “I like my eyes the best. I love playing with different make-up styles for my eyes and seeing how I can make them stand out.

“As a young girl, I was always frustrated at not being able to steal my mom’s make-up because she never had any.

“So getting into modelling and acting has allowed me to fulfil all my make-up dreams.”

These days Megan is nearly as famous for her body art as for her body.

She has at least ten tattoos including designs on her ribs and shoulder.

But she is currently getting a portrait of Marilyn Monroe on her right forearm removed, claiming it causes “negativity”.

And the process has been painful.

Megan explains: “Removing the tattoo is a hundred times worse than getting the tattoo itself. I think it will come off really easily, though, and I’m not going to put something over it.

“I have the right skin type for removing it, so I think it will look fine. They tell you when you come in that the more fair your skin is, the easier it is to remove.

“I’ve got three or four more sessions left to go. Even though I still love Marilyn Monroe, I was just over having the tattoo of her. I got it when I was 18, and now I’m 25.”

A big part of that growing-up process has been her relationship with former Beverly Hills 90210 star Brian Austin Green.

The couple have been together for seven years and got married in 2010. She is reportedly now expecting his child — but both Megan and Brian refuse to comment on the rumours.

However, the actress is more than happy to gush about life as “mom” to young stepson Kassius – Brian’s son by 90210 actress Vanessa Marcil.

She says: “A lot of things make me happy. But I feel unbelievably happy when my nine-year-old stepson tells me I’m beautiful. Kassius is one of the most beautiful things about my life.

“When I started living with Brian, his son was only two and I was 18. But ever since I’ve felt like we’ve created this family together.

“I’ve basically been looking after Kassius since he was three and that’s part of my world that very few people really ever understood about me.

“I love being a stepmom and I feel that the experience grounds me when nothing else makes sense in my life.”

The other grounding influence is her religious faith.

Megan, who was brought up in a strict Pentecostal family in Tennessee, reveals: “I’ve always found it strange that different Christian groups can look at each other in an antagonistic way.

“I think all religions have common principles and an overriding faith in God, so I’ve tried to use religion in a non-restrictive, very open way.

“I go regularly to a church in Los Angeles which is very open and non-judgmental. There I meet a lot of other young people who are looking to share their faith and find common meaning with other people.

“Religion can be a beautiful thing.”

Grating dictator

SACHA BARON COHEN’S latest creation – a crazed Middle Eastern dictator – has already caused Borat-style havoc around the world.

The latest stunt has seen gigantic portraits of despot Admiral General Shabazz Aladeen go up around the UK and the US.

Looking like tributes put up to real Middle East dictators the posters – surrounded by guilt frames – give no hint that they are spoof ads for the movie. They do not include the title or the May 18 opening date.

Promotion for the movie started early. In February, the British comedian turned up on the red carpet at the Oscars in character.

He was carrying an urn he said containing the ashes of North Korean dictator Kim Jong-il – which he spilled over the designer suit of horrified TV host Ryan Seacrest.

Then came the release of the movie’s website – which looks like a serious site for Aladeen’s (fictional) fiefdom, the Republic of Wadyia.

It contains links to Victoria’s Secret, described by the Wadyians as a site for “high class hookers”. Then there is a link to the UN, which is marked up as a comedy website.

It is not the first time the 40 year old, who first found fame as Ali G, has conducted bizarre publicity stunts for his films.

When promoting Borat in 2006 he arrived at the Toronto film festival in character as the Kazakhstani TV host in rickety cart pulled by “peasant women”.

pages.subdeck: Making a fresh start ... battered bride Tammy Driver
pages.headline: From bride to battered
pages.teaser: BEATEN up and accused of flirting, Tammy’s marriage is one of the shortest ever in UK
pages.articlebody:
FOUR days after their wedding, most brides are happily re-living the best day of their life.

But heartbroken newlywed Tammy Driver was nursing a suspected fractured cheek and broken nose.

And worst of all, she had suffered her terrible injuries at the hands of her new husband.

Tammy, 23, went from a blushing bride to a battered wife in just 96 hours, after Nicky Pearce accused her of flirting with his best man.

Pearce, 31, was jailed last month for a year after admitting to the assault on his new wife.

Now Tammy — whose marriage was one of the shortest ever in Britain — is bravely sharing her story because she wants to help other victims of domestic violence.

She said: “Just days after we pledged to stay together until death us do part, I was throttled and savagely beaten by my new husband after he accused me of flirting with his best man.

“I really thought I was going to die.

“He even cruelly smashed up all the wedding gifts in his frenzy of anger.

“I thought Nicky was the best thing to ever happen to me and I believed we were going to be together forever.

“But our marriage only lasted four days. It was a sick joke.

“It broke my heart to admit it was over so quickly but I was very lucky to get out of my marriage alive.

“I believe that once a man hits you, you should leave straight away.

“Domestic violence must never be tolerated.

“Since this has happened to me, I have learnt that two women a week die from domestic violence and that is so horrifying.”

Tammy, from Penrhiwceiber, South Wales, a full-time mum to four-year-old Adam, said: “I met Nicky at a party in 2009 and we clicked immediately.

“I already had a little boy and Nicky was a natural father. He would sit and play with Adam for hours. My son adored him.

“He did everything for me and always gave me fresh flowers. I couldn’t believe what a lucky girl I was.

“Early in the relationship Nicky was kind and thoughtful.

“He was quite insecure that I would cheat on him but he had never laid a finger on me.

“When Nicky got down on one knee after a five-month whirlwind relationship, I said yes straight away. I couldn’t wait to be his wife.”

The couple got married in June 2010.

Tammy added: “I cried with joy as I walked down the aisle. I was marrying the man of my dreams.

“It was the best moment of my life.

“On our wedding day he promised to love, protect and care for me.

“The next few days were heaven as we enjoyed a romantic honeymoon in a nearby hotel.

“Nicky told me over and over how much he loved me.”

Afterwards, they visited chef Curly Thomas, 28, Pearce’s best man. Tammy said: “We had a lovely afternoon laughing and sharing a few drinks.

“Nicky was silent on the way home, I thought it was because he had had too much to drink.

“When we arrived back at the house he flipped. He started screaming and shouting that I was all over Curly.

“I had never seen him so angry. I didn’t know who this man was. He certainly wasn’t the man I’d said my vows to four days earlier.”

Pearce threw Tammy against a door, gripped her around the neck and began to strangle her.

Tammy said: “He had his hands tightly around my throat and his face was contorted.

“He finally let go of me and I slumped to the floor, gasping for breath.

“He then stormed through the house smashing every cupboard with his fist. Our beautiful wedding gifts were smashed and left shattered on the floor.

“I cowered, begging him to calm down, but he hissed that he was going to kill me and then said, ‘If I can’t have you no one will.’

“With those terrifying words, he attacked me again, biting me and headbutting me in the face.

“I thought I was going to die. I just prayed it would be over quickly.”

Tammy lost consciousness as she watched blood pour on to the floor from her injuries.

If you or someone you know is a victim of

domestic violence contact the national helpline on 0808 2000 247.

She added: “When I came round Nicky was gone. I stumbled into the street, screaming for help.

“A neighbour took me in and called the police. I was rushed to hospital for treatment.

“I was unrecognisable, my face was so swollen and battered. I couldn’t believe the man I loved had done this to me.”

Tammy had suffered a broken nose, severe bruises and bite marks covered her face and neck.

She says: “The doctors were concerned my cheekbones were shattered from the bites but they couldn’t X-ray my face as it was so swollen.

“The police later told me it was the worst case of domestic violence they had seen.

“They had caught Nicky on the night of the attack.

“I realised how lucky I was to escape with my life — and to see my little boy again.

“I was so relieved Adam hadn’t been in the house at the time to witness the horror.

“Nicky almost managed to destroy my trust in men forever. It’s taken a long time to recover.”

But she is now learning to love again with painter and decorator Archie Andrews, 28.

Now nine months pregnant, Tammy said: “Archie is the love of my life.

“He is the sweetest, most protective, loving person I have ever met.

“We will get married once my divorce papers are through.

“My painful memories of Nicky fade with every day and my four-day marriage seems like a very bad dream.”

Additional reporting: JANE COHEN

pages.headline: Kinky Katy Perry is no role model for our little girls
pages.teaser: RELATIONSHIP expert explains why she agrees with David Cameron’s call to put 18 certificates on music videos
pages.articlebody:
DAVID CAMERON wants 18 certificates for raunchy music videos to stop children seeing explicit images of stars such as Katy Perry, Rihanna and Lady Gaga.

He warns that they are sexualising kids and putting pressure on young girls to dress like scantily clad pop idols.

Here, a top behavioural expert explains why she agrees with Mr Cameron.

I AM constantly speaking to parents who are deeply concerned about their children’s behaviour and self-esteem being damaged by a tide of inappropriate music videos and sexual behaviour of celebrities in the spotlight.

They are distressed at how their child is learning to dress or behave in a promiscuous way because they are exposed to sexy pictures and videos on a daily basis.

Parents have little control over what they are watching — most of these raunchy videos are played throughout the day and acts like Lady Gaga and Rihanna perform regularly in skimpy outfits before the watershed.

I completely agree with Cameron’s campaign. It’s time music videos were given a certificate rating.

I recently spoke with a couple who were distressed at their 12-year-old daughter’s behaviour. They told me she wanted to dress like “a hooker” when she went to her school disco and that she wanted to be “sexy” like her friends.

She also put pressure on her mother to buy a top that was practically see-through, because Rihanna worse something similar in a video.

The parents were extremely upset at their little girl even knowing the meaning of the word “sexy”.

But they can do little to shield her from this way of thinking when her idols are portraying themselves in this way. This couple are not alone — this battle is being fought by parents across the country. They feel their kids are losing out on innocent childhoods because of pop stars.

When Katy Perry is lying naked on a pink cloud singing about California girls wearing bikinis, it is a bad image for youngsters.

The parents I speak to find that their daughters are powerfully affected by the images and think it is a “cool” way to behave.

Adolescence is a time when young people can be hugely influenced by popular culture and as a society we have a duty to protect them from this negative way of behaving.

If they are constantly seeing gorgeous women gyrating in outfits suitable for lap-dancing clubs, this becomes the norm. It is what they think they should be like.

Adolescent boys are also influenced — they feel that they must live up to a “pimping” image. This means disrespecting women — as many rappers do in videos — and treating them like objects.

It’s sad that many young children I speak to feel all that counts is sexiness.

They do not think their personalities, or how accomplished they are, matter. Adults are past being influenced by the videos but the same is not true for teens.

We must make it clear that they should not be exposed to this content until they’re at an age where they have the confidence to filter out the negative and damaging messages.
