pages.headline: From vajazzle to tooth dazzle
pages.teaser: COSMETIC dentist to the stars reveals secrets behind the Essex girls’ gleaming teeth
pages.articlebody:
THE TOWIE effect has taken another bite of the beauty industry following the vajazzle, fake tan and hair extensions.

Now viewers are being inspired to brush up on their smiles after seeing the reality stars’ gleaming teeth.

Cosmetic Dentist Genevieve Keane from the Start Smiling clinic in Brentwood, Essex, looks after many of the TOWIE girls’ gnashers.

Here, she gives us the low-down on getting that picture-perfect smile.

Genevieve says: “I particularly like TOWIE newcomer Georgina Dorsett’s teeth. I think she has cared for them very well.

"She possibly had orthodontics when she was younger, plus she’s had them whitened. She is blessed with a beautiful smile.

"Billie and Sam Faiers both have great teeth too. The majority of the TOWIE crew have polar white teeth from whitening services and it is often accentuated by their dark tans.

“Before you proceed with any dental cosmetic procedures you need to ensure your teeth and gums are in optimum condition.

“We always advise patients to come for a free dental consultation and then a hygienist appointment, where their teeth will be cleaned, scaled and polished. You should try to have these every three months to keep your teeth and gums healthy.

“If you don’t have healthy teeth, any procedures you have will never last. If you have, say, veneers, instead of lasting from 15 to 20 years they will only last for five if you have a receding gum line.

“Our most popular treatment for the TOWIE look is whitening. We advise our younger patients to have the at-home whitening service.

“This isn’t as strong as the in-house service, laser whitening.

It costs around £390 for the take-home kit. This comprises syringes of peroxide bleach that are injected into a special mould, like a gum shield, that fits over the teeth. The patient wears this for one or two hours a day. It is a popular quick-fix treatment.

“Whitening should only ever be provided by a qualified dental practitioner. Don’t be fooled by ultra-cheap services as they could be practising illegally and not providing an effective or safe product.

“If young clients come to us asking for veneers, we tend to put them off because of their age. We don’t want to compromise the health of their teeth – you can get straight and even teeth without going down the veneer route.

“We advise them to have other treatments such as braces. There are so many that are inconspicuous these days, where they are clear in appearance or hidden behind the back of your teeth.

“Another simple but effective service is where we use composite (poly-resin) to build up teeth so they are all the same level. However, they must be maintained, as they can discolour or chip over time.

“Other popular teeth treatments for the TOWIE look include the Inman Aligner.

“This is a unique way of straightening crooked teeth with a removable brace that fits behind the teeth. It takes an average of six to 16 weeks to achieve excellent results.

“You can pop it out whenever you need to, so it’s perfect if you have a hot date. Holly Willoughby recently tweeted pictures of her aligner brace in a bid to improve her smile.

SKIRT lengths vary by 20ins as women go through life — and 23-year-olds wear the tiniest minis, a study found.

Confident women now wear mini-skirts until they hit 45, five years later than when the study was last carried out in 2009.

Girls first want a mini aged 14, but most settle for rolling up their 46cm (18in) school skirts until they buy one at 16.

They wear skirts averaging 36cms (14ins) until they’re 19. Hemlines are then hiked to 32cms (12.5ins) as 20 to 23-year-olds hit the town flirting.

Skirts lengthen 5cms as girls settle down with their first serious boyfriends, before going back up as 28 to 34-year-olds hunt husbands.

Lengths stay steady in women’s 30s, but turning 40 makes them flash flesh again in 35cm skirts. Hemlines fall below the knee at 49 and over-60s prefer maxi-skirts at least 80cms long. Debenhams, which did the study, said: “British women are still in love with the mini-skirt.”

pages.teaser: HOW ‘lusty’ sex line worker Maureen Gardner fools punters to rake in the cash
pages.articlebody:
AS Sexy Scarlett breathes heavily into the phone and describes her saucy fishnets and satin undies, the punter on the other end of the line would never imagine she was really 55-year-old Maureen Gardner.

Wearing tracksuit bottoms and nursing a cup of tea, with the phone wedged under her chin, she spends each evening pretending to be a lusty young callgirl to earn extra cash.

After midnight, the calls come in fast. From teenage lads to pensioners, Maureen has satisfied them all.

She says: “I’m such an actress, I even add sound effects to make their experience realistic. My favourite is flicking the elastic on my manky pop-socks.

“The snapping noise against my skin emulates the sound of the sexy fishnet stockings that I promise the men I am wearing. Of course, the reality is that I’m taking the bins out.”

Because there are no visuals with a phone call, it is important that Maureen describes herself with detail too.

She says: “I tell the men I’m tall and slim with jet-black hair down to my waist and I’m almost always holding a whip. In reality, I’m short with curly red hair and often carrying the iron.”

Maureen’s punters love to feel as if she is really in the room with them, so she has found some odd ways to make her sex noises as lifelike as possible.

She says: “I find that if I put my knees up to my neck, it compresses my diaphragm, then my groans sound pitch-perfect. I also watch When Harry Met Sally as homework. Meg Ryan was my sex noise idol. It really is quite amazing how gullible men are.”

Being a sex line worker wasn’t always the plan for Newcastle housewife Maureen. She says: “A few years ago I saw an advert in the local paper, saying ‘Tarot readers required’.

“It was a subject I’d always been interested in and I enjoyed doing readings for friends and family.

“When I called to enquire, I was told they were full on the tarot-reading line but had space on the sex line.”

After some doubts Maureen decided to give it a go. She says: “I had nothing to lose and what they were offering seemed perfect. I could do it from the comfort of my sofa and pick my hours.

“I simply had to log on to the chatline system using my home phone with a PIN number they gave me.”

Maureen created her alter ego Scarlett and says: “I remember thinking that the name Maureen just isn’t sexy enough. I didn’t want to sound middle-aged. That’s why Scarlett was born.

“Whenever the phone rings, I morph into her. Scarlett has worked as an air hostess and a make-up artist — and when it comes to the bedroom, she’s up for anything.”

Maureen’s aim is to keep callers on the phone for as long as possible because the longer the call lasts, the more she gets paid. She says: “I can earn up to £15 an hour. On a good day during peak time, I can earn 35 quid for a couple of hours on the phone.”

Fortunately, Maureen’s boyfriend Paul, a 50-year-old engineer, doesn’t have a problem with her unusual job.

She says: “I never work when he is in the house, out of respect. But he is as open-minded as me and knows I earn well out of it.

“Sometimes he would roll his eyes but he was fine with me doing it — as long as I didn’t tell him what the callers were saying to me.”

After a year in the job, Maureen stepped it up a gear and started working on the dominatrix lines too. This time her alter ego was Katia, a 6ft blonde Norwegian prison guard.

She says: “I would threaten in my best Scandinavian accent, ‘My bite is as bad as my bark.’ The men loved the idea of Katia and I felt pretty sexy pretending to be her. I even had some punters call from Hong Kong.”

She adds: “My friends all think I’m bonkers, especially my friend Maggie, who didn’t know how to react when I told her about my secret job.

“Thankfully, they don’t judge me and instead we laugh about it. I’m a bubbly character and they know I mean no harm by what I do.”

After doing the job for only a short while, Maureen realised she had quite a talent for acting and role play and decided to take a course in drama alongside her phone work.

She says: “I got a place at university in September 2010. I’ve always loved the idea of acting and I dream about playing a character like Lillian in Shameless.

“The course is in performing arts and drama — the perfect combination. I even did a rendition of Katia in my class once.

“I’ve decided to be open about my job — I’ve got nothing to hide. In fact I’m thrilled — my secret job has opened up a whole new life for me.”

Now in the final year of her course, Maureen is too busy for the chat lines and says: “It’s so funny how one thing can lead you on to something new. Although my course comes first, I would certainly go back to the sex lines in the future if I needed to financially.

“I know Scarlett and Katia will always be waiting in the wings, but for now I keep the saucy talk for my bedroom only.”

pages.subdeck: Ordeal ... Samina thought she was dressing up for her 5th birthday, not her wedding
pages.headline: I wed aged FIVE... in the UK
pages.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: SHOCKING case highlights plight of women as The Sun launches campaign to end child-bride misery
pages.articlebody:
DRESSED in a fancy new outfit, little Samina Shah thought she was getting ready for her birthday party.

Instead she was being married off — having just turned FIVE.

The Islamic ceremony effectively ended her childhood and paved the way for years of abuse.

Just as shockingly, this was not happening in a remote Third World village — but in a large town in the north of England.

Samina has decided to speak out after Britain’s Forced Marriage Unit revealed that last year the 1,468 cases they investigated included another girl of five.

There are thought to be another 6,500 cases that went unreported.

Samina — not her real name as she is too scared to be identified — told The Sun: “I was denied the right of childhood, play and innocence.

“When you are married at the age of five you no longer live like a normal child. I was deprived of my basic human rights.

“I’m genuinely shocked and horrified to hear that another little girl has had to go through this. My heart goes out to that child and anyone who is forced to marry.

“That is why I am sharing my experience, to reach out to those girls and young women. There is hope and light at the end of the tunnel.”

She went on: “I know that such behaviour is contrary to the teachings of Islam and must be therefore outlawed.

“There is no Islamic justification for forced marriage and doing it to a child of that age is not just wrong — it is criminal.”

Samina, now in her early 40s, rebuilt her life to become a successful business entrepreneur.

But she is still haunted by memories of beatings, brutality and repression.

Recalling her childhood wedding day, she said: “There was a lot of activity — a lot of relatives in the house. I was dressed up in an outfit mother-in-law had bought for me.

“My sister told me later that my mother-in-law had said, ‘At last, the beautiful girl belongs to me!’

“I don’t know exactly why I was married off at such a young age, but it was all to do with maintaining traditions and making sure we didn’t question anything.”

Samina was born into a typical Asian family in a close-knit community, keeping to the ways of their remote villages of northern Pakistan.

She was not encouraged in school work and was removed at 13.

Instead she was raised to believe a woman’s place was at home and the more she suffered, the greater the reward in Paradise.

On her 14th birthday a formal wedding ceremony was held, marking the bride’s transition from her parents’ home to the home of the husband.

At six the next morning, terrified for her future, she was bundled on to a plane to Pakistan.

She was told she would return to England with her husband when she reached 16.

She used to dread evenings when she would have to tearfully face the advances of her husband.

The marriage was eventually consummated against her will after she suffered a horrific beating.

After three months it was decided she should live under lock and key back in England until she turned 16.

Forced marriage in Britain comes under civil, not criminal, law. Many victims are sent abroad.

Those at risk can apply for a court order stopping them — or the marriage organisers — from leaving the country. Anyone breaking such an order can be jailed for up to two years for contempt of court.

Victims who do return to the UK find the marriage is not legally recognised — but whoever forced them into marrying cannot be prosecuted.

The Government is currently looking at changing the law.

Samina, who backs a change, remembers how she was not even allowed out into the garden.

She said: “I missed the sunlight on my face. I used to look out at kids playing and feel an overwhelming sense of envy.”

At the age of 20 Samina gave birth to a daughter. She said: “At that point I knew that there was no way that she would endure what I had been through.”

She became obsessed with cleanliness. Samina explained: “I felt like I’d been bottling up everything. I was scrubbing the house and then scrubbing myself, cleansing myself. I was trying to rub away stains of abuse.

“I’d been locked up and I locked my feelings up too.

“My husband insisted that I never reveal I had been married at such a young age. I had to say I was married at 16.

“But as my daughter went to school I got interested in studying again.”

Against her husband’s wishes she took GCSEs at college. After ten years she beat her obsessive compulsive disorder. And, at the age of 37, she left her husband.

She said: “It had got to the point where I wasn’t allowed to smile because smiling was said to be the sign of a loose woman, a woman who was flirting.”

Leaving was an incredibly brave move considering how it was deemed unacceptable for a Muslim woman to ask for a divorce.

Samina went back to her parents but ended up trudging the streets.

For the first time in the interview, Samina breaks down and sobs: “I was so upset, I thought everyone had abandoned me.”

Contemplating suicide, she started writing a text of apology to her daughter. She said: “Then I thought, how could I? She needed me — I couldn’t leave her.”

Samina found herself outside a church where she knew the priest.

She said: “I was so disheartened I wanted to abandon everything I had been taught in childhood.

“I thought the best thing I could do was to convert. Maybe being a Christian would give me peace.”

But the priest told her Islam had not let her down — people had.

He contacted a Muslim woman who gave Samina a bed for the night and a shoulder to cry on.

Eventually — with the help of friends, her daughter and one other relative — she got back on her feet and even made up with her family.

She said: “I stopped seeing myself through other people’s eyes. I finally realised I was not an inferior being. Deep down, I always had a belief that I would free myself.”

Samina now gives talks to women’s groups and is a mentor to youngsters.

She said: “Islam safeguards women’s rights, and I am delighted that I found the Islam that God sent down — not the one that has been hijacked by the jackals who misrepresent its true teachings.”

Girls’ lives must be theirs to live

By JASVINDER SANGHERA, Head of forced marriage charity Karma Nirvana

PEOPLE will be horrified that a five-year-old girl in Britain could enter into a marriage. Sadly, I am not at all surprised.

Alongside many others, her life was mapped out before her. Her life was not her own to live but for others to take.

Today there remain thousands at risk. Last week we delivered more than 2,500 postcards to Number 10. They showed 98 per cent of the British public say forced marriage should be made a criminal offence.

I’m not buying the idea that it should not be criminalised as it would just go deeper underground — it’s underground now.

We have a duty to bring it above the ground in the same way we treat domestic violence.

I would urge anyone who fears they are going to be coerced or forced into marriage to get in touch with us.

Or if they suspect that this is happening to a younger member of the family, then to get in touch too.

Our helpline is free and confidential. Please call 0800 5999 247.

8,000 reasons to bring in a ban

By PRITI PATEL Tory MP for Witham

THE most abhorrent aspect to this story is that this is current practice in Britain today.

Government estimates say there are up to 8,000 cases a year, most of them going unreported.

How can it be right for the very foundations of civil society — our police, our schools and community leaders — to turn a blind eye in this day and age?

Society’s abhorrence of such human mistreatment should be shown by making forced marriage a criminal offence.

Only then can we send out the strongest possible clear and unequivocal message to every community across Britain.

The Government recognises that the practice is wrong and has led the consultation into making forced marriage a crime.

The time has now come to do what is right by correcting the terrible injustices suffered by those forced into marriage against their knowledge and against their will by making this practice illegal once and for all.

a.baig@the-sun.co.uk

pages.headline: 7/7 Tube blast to Paralympics
pages.teaser: HOURS after toasting Britain getting the Olympics, Martine was hurt in Aldgate train blast
pages.articlebody:
A WOMAN who lost her legs in the 7/7 terror attacks last night spoke of her joy at being picked to represent Britain in the 2012 Paralympics.

And Martine Wright revealed that by a cruel twist of fate she was only on a Tube train that was blown up because she had spent the previous night celebrating London winning its Olympic bid.

In a moving interview Martine, 39, who will be part of Team GB’s sitting volleyball team, told The Sun: “I feel like I am meant to do this.

“If you had told me six years ago, when I was struggling to even sit up in bed, that one day I would be an elite sportswoman about to represent my country at the biggest sporting event on Earth — I would have thought you were off your rocker.”

Martine was on a Circle Line Tube train when fanatic Shehzad Tanweer detonated his bomb just outside Aldgate Station on July 7, 2005.

Now she feels it was part of her Olympic destiny. Martine will proudly wear the number 7 on her Team GB vest this summer — in memory of the fateful day that led to 52 deaths at the hands of al-Qaeda-inspired terrorists.

She said: “Some people might only see the negative in what happened to me. But I’m turning it into a positive.”

For Martine, London 2012 and the 7/7 horrors will always be tied together.

A day before the attacks, the International Olympic Committee announced London had won the bid to host the Games.

Martine, a marketing manager at the time, decided to have a few drinks with colleagues after work to celebrate.

It led to her spending an extra ten fateful minutes in bed next morning.

She missed her normal train, then a Northern Line signal failure meant she took the Circle Line to work.

She ended up sitting just 4ft from Tanweer when he set off his bomb.

Martine recalled: “There was a white flash. It felt like being in a Tom and Jerry cartoon and being hit in the face with a frying pan.

“That’s how it vibrated. Then the light went and all I could see was darkness.

“All you could smell was burning, and all you could hear were screams.

“I could see my brand new white trainer 8ft above all the debris.

“And I remember thinking ‘what’s it doing up there?’”

Martine lost three quarters of her blood before she was rescued.

She was in an induced coma for two weeks. Her body was so swollen that her brother and sister at first failed to identify her in hospital.

During that time Martine had 12 operations to amputate her legs above the knee.

She said: “I thought my life was over when I woke up and saw that my legs were gone. But when I found out how many people had died, I realised I was one of the lucky ones — and I needed to grab every opportunity.”

Martine, who now uses prosthetic legs as well as a wheelchair, married long-term boyfriend Nick, 39, and gave birth to Oscar, now 2½, soon after.

But she decided she wanted a new challenge and joined a sitting volleyball team after falling in love with the sport at a Paralympics taster day.

Martine said: “This is a whole new dream. It gives me the drive and ambition I used to feel at work.”

Sitting volleyball is played across a lower net than the regular game.

Players’ backsides must not lose contact with the floor when they hit the ball. Britain has not had an Olympic sitting volleyball team before.

By a strange coincidence, the British sitting volleyball team’s first international match was on July 7, 2010. Around this time, the team were regularly thrashed. But Martine says they are now ready to take on the best in the world this summer.

She said: “It felt like we had a mountain to climb at first.

“But we have started to get sets off teams that used to walk all over us.

“We might not be the most experienced team, but we can make sure we are the fittest and the strongest. With home advantage, anything can happen.”

But Martine’s journey has not been an easy one. She explained: “In the first days after I woke up in the hospital, it was so hard looking down at where my legs used to be and thinking, ‘My God, there’s nothing there’.

“I could barely look at myself in the mirror. It was only when I went up to the physio gym at the hospital and met other survivors I realised how many had died, and that I was one of the lucky ones. I’m still here. I’m still me.”

Martine threw herself into rehab but found the going tough.

She said: “Half your body is gone so it’s a whole balance thing.

“Your body can’t compute that all that weight is gone. So even to sit up in bed feels impossible.

“Learning to walk again with prosthetic legs was the hardest thing I ever had to do, physically and mentally.

“Having to deal with it every second of every day is overwhelming.

“But I was lucky enough to have brilliant medical and physio staff that made me strong again.” Martine went on to get her air pilot’s licence and even did a sky dive for charity. But sport is her real passion.

She said: “No one should underestimate what sport can give people. At university I played mainly hockey but at school it was all sorts.”

Surprisingly, Martine feels no bitterness about her fate. She said: “I have never been angry towards the bomber. I just thought what he did was a bloody selfish thing to do. But he was brainwashed. I know other survivors who still have nightmares, but I don’t.”

Instead, the sports star dreams of gold medals. She said: “It’s the biggest sporting event on Earth, and it’s coming to the city where I was born. What Londoner doesn’t dream of being part of it?”

WOULD you rather endure a nerve-racking job interview than face the world slap-free?

If you answered Yes, you are one of more than two thirds of women who say they would be too scared to face the world without their make-up.

And a staggering 91 per cent of women would cancel a first date rather than turn up barefaced.

Despite this, a new craze has hit Twitter where girls are exposing their faces first thing in the morning.

And celebrities are now jumping on the bandwagon.

Over the last week Hollywood A-lister Dakota Fanning, presenter Fearne Cotton, actress Pamela Anderson and pop superstar Lady GaGa have been pictured without their usual war paint.

So to see how a confirmed glamourpuss feels without her armour of make-up, Sun Woman asked high-maintenance Towie star Gemma Collins to go au naturel.

Gemma, 31, admits make-up acts as a safety blanket and gives her confidence.

She says: “When I wake up in the morning I have an awful habit of looking in the mirror. I look and think, ‘OMG I am going to need three hours to sort this mess out’.

“No man could ever see me like that. Without make-up on, you get another Gemma. I just feel very, very vulnerable, too open.

“I even talk differently without make-up, softer than normal.

“Without make-up you can really see what I am like as a person.

“Make-up is like wearing a suit to work – it makes you feel and act different. It changes me completely. I feel I can be more over the top with it on and make better decisions. Also, I feel protected.

“I can hide behind make-up if I’m sad or feeling not so confident. The minute I get my eyes on and bronzer applied, I feel very confident.

“Past partners have preferred me with no make-up, even in the morning. But when a relationship is new I would always creep into the bathroom before a boyfriend woke up and put on some blusher, eye drops, white eyeliner and perfume so I looked fresh.”

“I would leave the house without make-up on, but only to walk the dog, go to the gym or pop to Tesco.

“But I would not feel as confident in myself.”

Last night Diana said: “I had the greatest fun and it was great to work with Matt. The whole team were so friendly and warm.”

The alternative awards are Matt’s first solo telly gig while comedy partner David Walliams appears as a judge on Britain’s Got Talent.

Matt added: “He’s doing brilliantly on a show that isn’t The Voice, he’s writing books and he’s been swimming through poo, so this is my chance to do my own thing.”

pages.subdeck: Positive message ... Melinda Messenger appreciates natural beauty
pages.headline: 'I cannot wait to be old and grey'
pages.teaser: EX-PAGE 3 girl is looking forward to ditching the make-up and the glam clothes
pages.byline: By LEIGH HOLMWOOD, Deputy TV Editor
pages.articlebody:
MELINDA MESSENGER says she can’t wait to get older so she can ditch the make-up and the glam clothes – and longs for the day when her hair turns GREY.

The ex-Sun Page 3 girl declared that being 41 beats her twenties any day.

Melinda — who got dressed up for our Mad Men-style photo-shoot — said: “I relish getting older.

“I get really confused by all the messages that tell us how youth is better.

“No it’s not. Getting older is where it’s at. The self-knowledge, wisdom and experience, the richness to your life that you gain with age. I would not trade it for the world.

“People say young is beautiful. I don’t think so. There is such a beauty in a mature person. Something else shines through.

“I can’t wait to have really long grey hair like an old lady. I genuinely can’t. It is about not having to care about how I look.

“If I wasn’t on TV I would dread to think what I would look like. I don’t make much effort with myself. The only effort I do make is when I know I have got to appear in people’s living rooms.”

“I don’t like wearing make-up and when I’m at home I don’t care what I look like.”

Melinda first came to prominence as The Sun’s Page 3 “girl of the thrillennium” at the turn of the century — but says her glamour modelling days now feel like a lifetime ago.

She said: “It was a really brief amount of time but it has had some of the biggest impact.

“I feel a lot more comfortable and relaxed doing photoshoots now, it is a lot more fun. Back then it was kind of scary and intimidating. Now it is a nice bit of light relief.”

She added: “I have fond memories of that time, although I was very naïve — even though I was 27 years old at the time.

“It feels like another age. It is so different to my life now but I wouldn’t change it for the world — but I also wouldn’t do it again.”

Melinda — mum to Morgan, 12, Flynn, ten, and Evie, eight, — says she would support her daughter if she decided that she wanted to go into modelling.

She said: “I wanted to do glamour modelling and nobody was going to stop me at that time. If Evie really feels that is what she wants, I am behind her 100 per cent.

“I don’t measure success by status or money or job titles. I measure success by how fulfilled you are. That’s what success is.

“If my kids can find what they love and do it I will be the happiest mum on earth. That is all I want for all three.”

Melinda says she is most comfortable when at home with her kids and hubby Wayne Roberts, who she married in Bali in 1998.

She has previously spoken of the tough time the couple went through in 2008, when they split for eight months after Melinda said they had lost their “deep connection”.

But Melinda said things were now good at home — although they still have to work at keeping their relationship strong.

She said: “Me and Wayne are still together. We have still been working through a lot of stuff but it is good now. I am still constantly gobsmacked we are still together after what we have been through.

“It is amazing. It is something I really value but a relationship needs constant work.

“Our family is so important to us. That is what glues us together in the tough times and makes us want to work through our problems.

“We all have times when it is amazing and times when we are like, ‘Why are we together?’ and we probably always will to some degree. Of course it would be amazing to say we will be together for ever but we are constantly growing and changing.

“Who knows where we will be in the future but I like to think we will be together.”

Melinda said she is honest about her family life in the hope that it will help others who have also had tough times.

She said: “One of the things I used to struggle with was when people would portray us as having the perfect relationship.

“It is unfair and sets an unfair ideal for others to measure themselves against. The reality is there is little in life that is perfect — you just do the best you can.

“I don’t like to pretend I’m anything I’m not and there is nothing wrong with me being me, flaws and all.

“I hope it does help other people to think, ‘Thank God, we are not the only ones.’

“I hope it would give hope to other people in a relationship. We have been together for 16 years now. We can weather the storm and come out the other side. “People sometimes think when you are a celebrity you have this kind of immunity but fame and money doesn’t buy you that. If anything it can make things harder.”

Melinda admitted that being a working mum was also tough at times.

She said: “The children are growing up really quickly. It can be a struggle to get the balance right.

“The work I do is massively demanding as it means I have to travel and be away from home so it means I have got to be strict about my priorities and what I take on.

“At half-term we went down to St Ives and I turned down three jobs that were really amazing and well-paid but the time with my kids was more important.

“It is hard when I have to leave in the morning and they don’t want me to leave. That pulls on my heart strings. Being a working mum you feel pulled in all directions.”

Melinda is back on the box tonight in new Channel 5 series Cowboy Traders, which sees her investigate dodgy dealings — something she found upsetting.

She said: “The new series has been amazing. After doing Cowboy Builders, I thought there couldn’t be anything else that gets me in quite the same way but this programme is something else again.

“We are looking at all different areas. There was one story where an elderly couple bought a mobile home and put their life savings into it and moved to France waiting for it to arrive... but it never did. They had been conned.

“That is their future over. They fought through the war for this to happen. It was heartbreaking stuff.

“I try to leave work at work but sometimes I lie in bed at night thinking about it.

“I do find it hard. It is really tough emotionally. My consolation is that we try and do what we can for the people on the show.”

Cowboy Traders is on at 7pm.

pages.byline: By LEIGH HOLMWOOD, Deputy TV Editor
pages.articlebody:
SIMON Cowell fears he will have to ditch his Mr Nasty image — to save Britain’s Got Talent from a ratings kicking by rival The Voice.

Cowell, 52, may soften his style after the “more gentle” BBC1 show The Voice averaged more viewers than ITV1’s BGT on Saturday.

An insider said: “He’ll learn lessons from it.”

The Beeb’s new show pulled in an average 9.5million viewers compared to BGT’s 9.1million.

The Voice also had a bigger share of the audience at 41 per cent when it aired between 7pm and 8.20pm.

BGT pulled in 37 per cent when it was on between 8pm and 9.15pm.

The gap between the shows WIDENED to nearly four million in the 20 minutes they went head to head.

Viewers took to Twitter to praise The Voice’s “positivity” — and they stuck the boot into BGT, in which judges buzz off acts they dislike.

An insider said: “Simon wasn’t happy when he saw the ratings. He likes to be number one in everything he does. He has told producers they must make BGT even better.

“He is known as being a perfectionist and this will will only renew his desire to beat The Voice.”

To add insult to injury, Cowell’s former X Factor judging pal Cheryl Cole praised The Voice, which features her pal Will.I.Am.

Ignoring BGT, Cheryl tweeted: “He is soo cheeky and mischievous! I love his and Jessie’s banter.”

Cowell fears the success of The Voice could damage his X Factor cash-cow and has demanded that BGT wrenches back the Saturday night ratings crown from the BBC.

He will take some comfort from BGT getting a higher peak figure, 11.3million to The Voice’s 10.7million. But the source said: “The big fear is that viewers will start seeing The Voice as the leading singing show.

“That would mean the best singers flocking to apply to it instead of The X Factor — and these shows live or die on their talent.

“Simon always learns lessons. He will be seriously considering whether he has to be nicer to contestants.

“He has softened his Mr Nasty image over the years. But maybe now he needs to turn fully into Mr Nice. It’s clear viewers are starting to get a taste for more positive shows.”

BGT bosses believe HUMOUR will be their trump card — especially now David Walliams is a judge. Viewers love the bickering between the Little Britain comic and Cowell.

A source said: “One of the criticisms of The Voice is that there isn’t enough humour in it. BGT has it in spades. You’ll definitely see more of David’s silly run-ins with Cowell.”

A pal of Cowell defended BGT last night, saying: “It’s feel-good, a warm family show. It doesn’t take itself too seriously or milk sob stories.”

The battle between the shows has in fact pushed ratings up for both.

Magnanimous Cowell tweeted well done to BBC1 boss Danny Cohen.

He wrote: “A slightly irritated congrats. But you didn’t have a dancing dog!” He went on: “I thought our team made a fantastic show last night. Loving the show this year.”

His spokesman added: “Simon is happy with the ratings. The judges are looking forward to the live shows.”

The BGT judge, 33, partied until the early hours yesterday at The Rose Club in central London.

It was the 20th time Chelsea have conceded a goal in the last 10 minutes this season.

Di Matteo said: “It’s a pattern, not killing off the opposition and then conceding late on.

“The biggest disappointment is that we were leading this game for such a long time.”

Chelsea had taken the lead through Frank Lampard’s 45th-minute penalty after Salomon Kalou went down.

Not many in the stadium were sure if Fulham’s Danny Murphy or Stephen Kelly had been penalised by ref Mark Clattenburg.

But boss Di Matteo said: “There was contact from Kelly and the ref was well positioned. I saw the replay and it was a penalty.

“We didn’t pose enough threat after that. If you manage to get a second goal, it gives the opposition less hope. But, at 1-0, it’s always shaky.”

The draw leaves Chelsea in sixth place in the Premier League, although they move a point closer to Spurs.

Di Matteo said: “We have been playing catch-up all season, so the situation for fourth was difficult for us from the start.

"But we have to look at it positively. We’re a point closer to fourth spot and we are closer to Champions League qualification than we were a month ago.

“It is going to go right down to the last game. Arsenal have got a bit of a gap now, so it’s looking like it will be three teams going for fourth place.”

Fulham boss Martin Jol said: “It was a soft penalty and it was all a bit confusing. We thought it was Danny but he touched the ball.

“The ref said Kelly but that was an accidental collision. I thought Kalou tripped himself.

“But we deserved the point. They didn’t cause us many problems.”

The former Tottenham manager added: “I think Spurs will finish fourth, they have all the quality. Spurs fans should be happy with us.”

pages.headline: Ell 4 Harry
pages.teaser: TOTTENHAM boss insists side are now battling for fourth not third after Norwich defeat
pages.articlebody:
HARRY REDKNAPP insists Tottenham are now fighting for fourth place not third after Elliott Bennett’s winner for Norwich.

Spurs have won just one of their last eight games and Redknapp admitted: “It’s going to be close, it’s the team that wants it most.

"There are still five games to go but I don’t think we have to win all five.

“Chelsea have to play Newcastle — they can’t both win.”

Spurs’ defeat left them two points behind third-placed Arsenal — who play at Wolves on Wednesday.

But they are only ahead of Newcastle on goal difference and two points clear of Chelsea.

Redknapp added: “We’d settle for finishing fourth. It would be lovely to finish above Arsenal but it’s still all to play for.

“Newcastle are playing great, so it’s going to be tight.”

Redknapp insisted he did not take any chances after leaving Emmanuel Adebayor, and Rafa van der Vaart on the bench while Scott Parker missed out with a hamstring problem.

John Ruddy pulled off a stunning stop to deny Benoit Assou-Ekotto and Gareth Bale hit the bar moments before Elliott Bennett’s stunning winner for Norwich.

Redknapp added: “We had some great chances but today was a setback. All to play for though, still.”

Norwich boss Paul Lambert hailed his heroes who are now level on points with eighth-placed Liverpool.

He said: “It was the best performance in the three years I’ve been here. That’s the magnitude of it.”

But Lambert also slammed referee Michael Oliver for denying the visitors TWO stonewall penalties at White Hart Lane.

Ledley King pulled Grant Holt down on the half-hour — moments before Jermain Defoe cancelled out Anthony Pilkington’s opener.

And in the second half sub Adebayor upended Canaries’ Aaron Wilbraham.

Lambert fumed: “King’s tackle wouldn’t have looked out of place at Murrayfield.

“Everyone in the ground saw that was a penalty, but we didn’t get it and we got hurt the other end.

“I thought Wilbraham’s was one as well. I don’t know how he missed that. It’s bizarre.”

pages.teaser: TOON manager last night targeted a £35m Euro prize, blasting: “We’re going for it”
pages.articlebody:
ALAN PARDEW last night set his sights on a £35million Champions League prize blasting: “We’re going for it.”

The Newcastle boss saw his marvellous Magpies move within two points of third place after finally seeing off battling Bolton at St James’ Park.

Hatem Ben Arfa’s 60-yard wonder run and goal plus Senegal striker Papiss Cisse’s 10th strike of the season helped Toon complete five straight league wins for the first time in six seasons.

Pardew insisted: “I said if we could be in there with a shout of the Champions League then we’d give it a go.

"That’s what we are going to do with the five games we’ve got left. That’s what our fans want to see us try to do. I have never ruled out the Champions League.”

Pardew reckons his side will be all but guaranteed a Europa League spot if Liverpool beat Everton in next Saturday’s FA Cup semi-final.

But he has got his eyes on the bigger prize — and the £35m boost to Toon coffers — which would cap one of the most remarkable seasons in their history.

He added: “If the semi-final results go our way we could be in Europe by next weekend.

“We have got to keep our eye on the ball and we are not giving up on anything.”

Pardew hailed his French wizard Ben Arfa after his mazy 60-yard run and sublime finish broke the deadlock.

And he urged national boss Laurent Blanc to include him in his European Championships squad — even if he could end up shooting down England.

Pardew added: “It was a truly special goal from a player who has magic in his feet.

“He should definitely have a chance with the French squad as there are not many players that can do that.”

Bolton boss Owen Coyle insisted his side can still beat relegation.

He said: “We deserved to be leaving here with something.

“I’ve told the players that if we continue to perform like that we will be in the Premier League next season.”

pages.headline: Fulham 1 Chelsea 1
pages.teaser: CLINT DEMPSEY headed home to prevent Blues drawing level with fourth-placed Spurs
pages.articlebody:
CHELSEA will struggle to crack a chocolate Easter egg let alone the top four.

Dreadful defending and a late Clint Dempsey equaliser saw them blow a big chance to go level with Tottenham.

Instead, caretaker-boss Roberto Di Matteo’s luck ran out and his team is now stuck in sixth place with five games to go.

They have only themselves to blame.

The Blues were eight minutes from a hard-earned win which bore all the hallmarks of the old Chelsea.

But that team would never have surrendered like this.

Frank Lampard hit a controversial first-half penalty that looked like being decisive.

But what they failed to do was make the most of it having been armed with the knowledge of Spurs’ earlier defeat. Three points and a 1-0 win would have put a revived Chelsea into fifth place, behind Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final opponents by just one goal.

Now they must rely on Tottenham slipping up again with so few games left — and Chelsea have the much harder run-in.

A costly lapse in concentration at the back only puts more pressure on, with so many other key games looming.

Just three days after Sunday’s Wembley showdown with Spurs, comes Barcelona in the Champions League semi-final.

After this draw, winning the big one looks like being the only way they will be back in Europe again next season.

Chelsea were eventually lucky to get out of their neighbours’ house with a point, such was the pummelling they took in the final stages of a match which slowly got into gear after Lampard tucked away his spot-kick.

It had been all Fulham until then too, as Martin Jol’s eye-catching side tested Petr Cech.

An interchange between Moussa Dembele and Dempsey in the 26th minute eventually led to a shot from the in-form American.

But it was too slow and Chelsea’s keeper covered the danger comfortably.

Just 60 seconds later, Kerim Frei exploded into the area.

The young midfielder wriggled past John Terry, Branislav Ivanovic and Gary Cahill with a neat twist then let rip with a low shot, which was heading goalwards until Cech launched himself and tipped the ball round his near post.

With bodies firmly behind the ball and Fulham’s full-backs throwing themselves in the path of everything, Chelsea were reduced to a few lame, long-range efforts.

Fernando Torres had an effort deflected over the bar, Salomon Kalou shot straight at Mark Schwarzer from 25 yards and Lampard fired off a wayward shot on 31 minutes.

That almost cleared the Hammersmith End of the Cottage.

Then fate, or the referee stepped in, just as the officials played a big part in Saturday’s hugely fortunate 2-1 win over Wigan which kept the Di Matteo bandwagon rolling along.

On 45 minutes, ref Mark Clattenburg gave a penalty to Chelsea which left Fulham raging even as everyone trooped off at half-time.

Kalou darted into the box only to be met by Danny Murphy. The Fulham skipper got the ball but also showed studs to the Chelsea forward who tumbled over.

Lampard was more precise this time with his finishing, neatly placing a shot low and to the right of Schwarzer to claim his 150th Prem goal.

Murphy hounded Clattenburg at half-time — arguing the case that if he had shown studs, why had he not been booked.

It was a justifiable argument and later it was suggested the penalty was given for right-back Stephen Kelly’s foul on Kalou a split second earlier.

Whatever it was for, it was hard cheese on Fulham who had led the way in open play.

Chelsea appeared to have their minds on their forthcoming semi-finals — when the chase for fourth place should also be a priority. They emerged far more energetic in the second half. Lampard went close with a left-foot curler and had a shout for a second penalty when shoved by Brede Hangeland.

Fulham rose to the increased tempo, too. In particular, teenager Frei teased Chelsea, drawing a series of fouls.

The pressure mounted and, eventually, Fulham got their reward. Cech made a stunning save at a corner from Aaron Hughes’ header.

But 30 seconds later a second set-piece came in and Dempsey rose unchallenged to flick home his third goal in two games to knock the stuffing out of Chelsea.

pages.subdeck: MATCH-WINNER ... Elliott Bennett goes wild after putting Norwich ahead
pages.headline: Tottenham 1 Norwich 2
pages.teaser: ELLIOTT BENNETT netted a stunner to dent Tottenham's hopes of a top-four finish
pages.articlebody:
APPARENTLY, an FA approach to Harry Redknapp for the England job will unsettle Tottenham in their bid for Champions League qualification.

What difference would it make now? While Spurs wait for the inevitable they are blowing up in spectacular style.

In fact, they could miss out on European football completely if they carry on the way they are, having won only one of their last eight Premier League games.

But this tale should not only be about Tottenham’s failure.

This was one of the most outstanding performances seen at White Hart Lane since Redknapp took over — and it came from a Norwich team which bossed the show.

Elliott Bennett’s cracking 66th-minute strike sealed a deserved victory for the East Anglians.

Paul Lambert’s men never stopped harassing Spurs from first whistle to last and would not allow their opponents to indulge in any of the champagne football which has become their trademark.

Redknapp admitted City striker Grant Holt, 30 — who is also being tipped for an England job — bullied his defence.

That will not do Holt’s chances of going to the Euros any harm if Harry takes over.

Interestingly, every one of the players in Canaries’ starting line-up was English born. Only Russell Martin, who has been capped by Scotland, does not qualify to pull on a Three Lions jersey.

Lambert described the Norwich display as the best in his three years at the club where he first assumed control when they were in League One.

He took over after City had been beaten 7-1 by the side he then managed, Colchester.

From such humble beginnings to winning at Spurs and doing it in such style speaks volumes for Lambert’s influence.

Lambert, Newcastle’s Alan Pardew and Swansea chief Brendan Rodgers, are all candidates for Manager of the Year.

They have given the Premier League an extra dimension with their refreshing approach.

Frankly, Spurs were flat as your hat and they will have to raise their game considerably before they face Chelsea in Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final at Wembley.

They were behind on 13 minutes when Younes Kaboul lost out to Anthony Pilkington and, although Kyle Walker tried to clear, the ball rebounded back off Ledley King.

It fell straight back to Pilkington, who converted comfortably.

Gareth Bale’s rasping cross almost brought Spurs an equaliser but Jermain Defoe just failed to connect as he slid in.

Then came a big moment of controversy as Holt muscled his way into the box and was clearly dragged down by King.

Referee Michael Oliver was unmoved by Norwich appeals and City lost their concentration, giving the ball away and letting Spurs get back on level terms.

Pilkington allowed Walker to take the ball off his toe and Jake Livermore stepped in to release Defoe with a delightful pass.

Defoe’s finish was quality as he dinked the ball over keeper John Ruddy and just inside the post.

Lambert slammed his water bottle into the ground and it must have bounced 30 yards down the touchline. Fourth official Phil Dowd was also left in no doubt of the visiting boss’ views about the incompetence of his colleague Mr Oliver.

For all that, Norwich did not let their heads drop. If anything it made them more determined.

They did well to keep Spurs at bay, first when Martin threw himself at Bale’s shot and then as Ruddy saved brilliantly to deny Benoit Assou-Ekotto following a lovely one-two with half-time sub Emmanuel Adebayor — on for the ineffective Louis Saha.

Keeper Ruddy, 25, is another who Redknapp might have noted with a view to the Euros.

Norwich had more justified appeals for a penalty as Adebayor seemed to flatten Aaron Wilbraham just inside the box, but referee Oliver again let play carry on.

Had Bale scored when he cut inside and rattled a shot against the underside of the bar, who knows what Lambert would have done to fourth official Dowd.

No matter how aggrieved Lambert felt, he need not have worried because Bennett, 23, then produced that wonder strike — his first goal for the club - to settle the match.

The midfelder collected the ball by the right touchline and let rip a 20-yard strike into the far corner which gave Brad Friedel no chance.

“We are staying up,” sang the travelling supporters.

They do themselves a dis-service. Norwich are so much more than mere survivors.

pages.subdeck: OFFICER DRIBBLE ... Hatem Ben Arfa celebrates his incredible goal
pages.headline: Newcastle 2 Bolton 0
pages.teaser: HATEM BEN ARFA scored a trademark wondergoal as Toon boosted their hopes of European football
pages.articlebody:
HATEM BEN ARFA opened his box of tricks to keep Newcastle dreaming of the Champions League.

The magical Frenchman scored a 73rd-minute pearler to spark wild celebrations in the stands and from boss Alan Pardew in the dugout.

Before that the match was dire and proving one hell of a frustrating afternoon for the Toon.

Bolton were defending for their lives, creating the best chances and a good bet to bag at least a point.

Then something truly special took place — an unforgettable, game-changing moment.

Ben Arfa collected a pass from Yohan Cabaye in Newcastle’s half on the edge of the centre-circle, almost 60 yards from goal. A sweet Johan Cryuff turn started it off as he sensationally skipped and danced past four Bolton challenges.

The ball seemed magnetically stuck to his feet.

He went this way and that, before sweetly dinking it past on-rushing defender David Wheater and beyond keeper Adam Bogdan.

It was a brilliant, wonderful goal that Leo Messi would have been proud of.

Perhaps, it was not as sensational as the Diego Maradona- like effort he scored at the start of the year against Blackburn in the FA Cup.

That was also a beauty. But make no mistake this was right behind it.

Ben Arfa has proved the most frustrating of players at times.

Yet, something seems to have finally clicked in his head. The goods are being produced on a far more regular basis by a guy who is clearly blessed with bucketloads of world class ability.

Boss Pardew should also take a bow for the way he has handled a player who has not been the easiest to manage.

It must be remembered what a massive win this was for Newcastle’s Euro push, leaving them right in the mix for a Champions League place.

Ben Arfa’s goal settled frayed nerves before Papiss Cisse kept up his remarkable scoring run to seal the deal late on.

With Toon flying so high there is an expectation of them ploughing through teams.

Pardew’s men have not lost at home since December but the problem was, Bolton turned up on Tyneside organised, compact and ready to compete.

The Trotters knew a performance on par with the pitiful home defeat to Fulham at the weekend could not be repeated. And their gameplan worked a treat until Ben Arfa struck.

The first half was, for want of a better word, awful. Chances were at a premium.

Owen Coyle’s strugglers were having their moments. Martin Petrov wriggled into the box just after the half-hour but his low shot was straight at keeper Tim Krul.

Toon’s Fabricio Coloccini, back after two games out with a hamstring strain, curled a shot straight at Bogdan.

Yet, as the first half ticked towards the end, we were still waiting for a decent opening from either side.

With Coyle packing the midfield and using striker Kevin Davies as his lone battering ram, it was always going to be this way.

The challenge for Toon was to, somehow, unlock the door. Two minutes after the re-start, though, they should have been behind.

Chris Eagles evaded Coloccini’s tackle only to be denied by Krul’s legs from eight yards.

It was the best chance of the game.

At this point, the visitors looked most likely to break the deadlock. And Petrov sent a cross flashing dangerously across the box soon after.

Another chance went begging for Bolton when Mark Davies was free in the box but fluffed his lines.

Newcastle hauled off Ba for Shola Ameobi on 64 minutes. He was not happy about it as he brushed off Pardew’s attempted handshake.

The Senegalese, who has now gone nine games without a goal, is not enjoying seeing his star stolen by international team-mate Cisse. But French schemer Ben Arfa could soon eclipse both of them.

Toon were struggling to carve open Bolton and it needed something special. Well, boy oh boy, did Ben Arfa deliver with just 17 minutes left. His balance, poise and control were a joy to behold.

Pardew’s crazed celebration said it all and when Cisse, looking suspiciously offside, bagged his 10th goal in his last nine games from Ameobi’s cross, the match was over.

Newcastle march on. Their Champions League dream is alive thanks to a fifth win on the bounce.

But this is a game which will always be remembered for one of the great Premier League goals.

Magnifique.

pages.subdeck: POINTING THE WAY ... David Moyes saw his side cruise home
pages.headline: Everton 4 Sunderland 0
pages.teaser: EVERTON went goal crazy to blow away Sunderland at Goodison Park
pages.articlebody:
DAVID MOYES will head to Wembley facing another derby selection dilemma.

And this time he could not be happier about it.

A month ago, the Goodison gaffer was slammed for making five changes for the league trip to Anfield, when Everton were thumped 3-0.

Yesterday, he did it again and was rewarded with the Toffees’ biggest win since they put five past Blackpool 13 months ago.

And, even more importantly, it leaves Moyes hugely spoilt for choice as he goes into Saturday’s FA Cup semi-final against Liverpool with just about everyone in peak form.

Take Magaye Gueye as the prime example, the unknown French winger who is suddenly bang in the frame to play at Wembley.

With just four league starts to his name, there are even a few Everton fans to whom the 21-year-old is a mystery man.

But a fortnight ago he took one of the starring roles as Moyes’ men booked their last-four ticket with a sixth-round replay win at the Stadium of Light.

Yesterday the rookie was at it again, scoring one and taking a key role in the next two as Martin O’Neill’s Sunderland were torn to shreds.

With Steven Pienaar cup-tied, it was not so much of a gentle nudge to manager Moyes as a size nine right up the backside.

And Gueye — battling with Royston Drenthe for that wide-boy role in London — is certainly in there with every chance.

Assistant boss Steve Round admitted: “Magaye was terrific today.

“We were disappointed with him at Norwich at the weekend and he was taken off at half-time, so he knew what was acceptable and what wasn’t.

“But he responded brilliantly. His energy, effort and link-up play were first class and we were really pleased.

“He is a great character, trains well and certainly has the ability.”

Gueye struck seven minutes after the break to set up Moyes for his first league win over O’Neill at the 10th attempt.

As James McFadden’s corner was not properly cleared, South African Pienaar headed it square for fellow midfielder Leon Osman to strike.

And when his thunderbolt came back off Black Cats keeper Simon Mignolet, Gueye was in like a shot to drill the rebound home at the near post for his first Everton goal.

Sunderland, frankly, were a huge disappointment and from that minute on it only ever looked a case of how many for Everton, with McFadden, Marouane Fellaini and Denis Stracqualursi all going close.

Not that they were ever going to pay for blowing those openings, with the Black Cats’ one and only chance — and no more than a half chance at that — coming when a Kieran Richardson cross caused a brief moment of panic.

But any home nerves were swiftly calmed with two goals in 60 seconds — and both a carbon copy of each other.

First, the hugely impressive Pienaar took a Gueye pass and curled the neatest of side-footed efforts in off Mignolet’s far post to make it 2-0.

And then, as Gueye looped another pass to Osman, we got an even more clinical finish off the woodwork.

Just to rub salt into the wounds, Victor Anichebe made it four after stepping off the bench.

His volley struck Jack Colback on the chest to leave Mignolet with no chance — and O’Neill ruing a bad day at the office.

The Sunderland boss admitted: “Everton were stronger and deserved to win. We looked a little tired and have lots to learn — we have lots of work to do.”

The visitors were forced to makes changes before and during the game after Saturday’s battling home draw against Tottenham and O’Neill added: “We were missing Nicklas Bendtner but should have been able to get on with that.

“We have had to make changes a lot this year, with players playing out of position — but that’s no excuse because we were well beaten.

“A few seniors players, like Lee Cattermole and Phil Bardsley, were carrying injuries going into the game and early in the second half you could see they were struggling.

“But they’ve got good hearts and wanted to play.

“Sometimes the scoreline can be misleading but we’ve been beaten 4-0 and deservedly so.”

It means Everton go to Wembley on the back of just two defeats in 16, while rivals Liverpool lurch from one disaster to another.

Even so, Round tried a somewhat cumbersome attempt at kidology — which was fooling no one — by claiming Kenny Dalglish’s Reds are favourites.

Round claimed: “We have momentum but a derby is a one-off, a semi-final is a one-off and when you put them together there is an element of luck about it.

“I still think Liverpool are the favourites. They have so many good players and it is such a good club with history and tradition.”

History and tradition maybe, Steve, but it is hard to remember the last time either of those two hit a winning goal — and Liverpool cannot buy one at the moment.

Somehow, the replica FA Cup being paraded around the corporate boxes before kick-off at Goodison may soon be replaced by the real thing.

pages.headline: Balo must go but Mancini needs time
pages.teaser: IAN WRIGHT answers the key questions about Manchester City’s two biggest names following their title meltdown
pages.articlebody:
HAS Mario Balotelli blown it for good this time?

When you have someone like Jose Mourinho — who has a reputation as one of the finest man-managers around — saying Balotelli is unmanageable, then it’s clear you have a major problem on your hands.

Roberto Mancini has been very, very patient and given him more chances than he’d get off most.

But although people said Mario was the man who could win City the title, in my book he’s done more to cost them.

Apart from a couple of important penalties and the odd flash of brilliance, I’ve not seen it.

In fact, his temperament in the last knockings of the title race has proved he is more of a liability.

HOW can they sort him out — if at all?

It seems there is simply no respect from Balotelli for anyone at the club.

When I was at Palace, if Jim Cannon flashed me a glance in a certain way I’d know I was out of line and I made sure I got it right.

Likewise at Arsenal, when Tony Adams gave you a look he didn’t need to say anything because you just knew.

It came down to respect, but Mario has none.

In some ways he reminds me of those kids running round in the riots.

Out of control, with no respect for anything or anyone.

And before people think that’s over the top, I’m not suggesting he’s going to go berserk — I’m just saying the attitude seems very similar.

Yes, they’ve had their blips at United over the years, but the big thing is they are all in it together and they are all winners, from the kids’ teams upwards.

Anyone who doesn’t buy into that theory, or totally agree with it, and it is a case of get rid.

And Fergie has got it right so many times that we know that’s the way to do it.

City need to learn that, because if they don’t, this season won’t be the exception, it will be the norm.

WHAT’S wrong with him?

I’d love to be proved wrong, but I’m certain I won’t be.

They say that if you don’t know you’ve got a problem, how do you solve it — and it seems to me Balotelli doesn’t know, or think, he has one. Look at that tackle on Scott Parker. Look at the challenge on Alex Song.

Look at the way he’s lunged into the tackle on Bacary Sagna, when all he needed to do was shadow him.

There is absolutely nothing about Balotelli that tells me he can win City the title for many, many years — if they kept hold of him.

But I simply don’t know if he has it about him to learn or to change.

Or to want to, for that matter.

And at the moment you just KNOW he will always do something to derail you.

WHAT damage does someone like that have on everyone else?

You only need to look across the city to how they do things at United to see the answer to that.

Wayne Rooney’s had his problems at times, but they all came through that because of the manager and how he handled things.

They still sing Eric Cantona’s name on the terraces and, once again, you have to take your hat off to Fergie for such brilliant man-management in getting all he did from the Frenchman.

Rooney clearly learned his lesson, maybe United learned a few as well, and look what it’s going to bring them — a 20th league title.

United must be laughing their socks off. No need for Fergie to try any of his mind games this season, because City have done it for him.

IS Balotelli just being used as a convenient scapegoat?

I do think there’s some of that, yes. But others have to be in the spotlight too.

City bought him in the first place, they’ve stuck with him when plenty wouldn’t, so the blame has to be shared. And what none of this should do is mask the fact the team and the manager have both under-achieved, when you look at the money they’ve spent and the dreams they had.

You can have all the cash in the world but if you haven’t got unity, it won’t count for anything.

And that seems to have been a problem throughout.

Don’t forget the Carlos Tevez saga — which, in a way, highlights the problem Mario has become, simply through the fact no one is really talking about the Argentinian any more. I think some of the other senior players could play a part as well and try and pull Balotelli into line.

Then again, I’m not convinced they could.

WHAT should City do with him?

Personally I’d get rid of him, but I don’t think it’s as simple as that.

It’s OK saying ‘Let’s sell him,’ but who in their right mind would want to spend big, big money on undoubted potential, but proven trouble?

City are going to have to take a massive hit on the £20million they paid for him. Just like they will on Carlos Tevez and Emmanuel Adebayor as well.

He just always seems so surly, sulky and angry.

He never seems to be enjoying himself, never seems to get pleasure from it, when he’s living the dream.

If City want to shed that noisy neighbours tag, they must leave players like Balotelli behind.

If not, they’ll not win that title for many, many years.

One bad apple can affect the whole fruit bowl.

And believe me, he will cost them far more than he will ever give.

SHOULD Mancini stay in charge for next season?

I would stick with Mancini as manager, certainly for the opening months of next season at least.

If City is, as they constantly tell us, a long-term project, then you need stability in the manager’s office.

If they start building a team around someone like Yaya Toure, who has been a big success, then you never know.

So at least give Mancini a chance to right the wrongs of this season — and one of the biggest wrongs of all is Balotelli and his attitude.

pages.subdeck: HEADS UP ... Robert Huth bags the leveller for Stoke
pages.headline: Aston Villa 1 Stoke 1
pages.teaser: ROBERT HUTH scored for the second time in 48 hours to earn Tony Pulis' side a deserved point at Villa Park
pages.articlebody:
ROBERT HUTH was Stoke’s set-piece saviour as his second goal in 48 hours earned the Potters a point.

A stunning first-half strike from Austrian striker Andi Weimann appeared to have edged Villa ever closer towards Premier League safety.

But the German struck after 71 minutes to bullet home his fifth goal of the season — and his 12th goal from a dead-ball routine since arriving from Middlesbrough 2½-years ago.

Huth has consistently proved himself to be head and shoulders above other Premier League defenders in the air.

But Villa boss Alex McLeish complained bitterly the Stoke stopper had climbed all over James Collins and blasted referee Mike Dean for failing to spot the blatant foul.

Big Eck rapped: “I’m disappointed we didn’t get a second goal to put it beyond Stoke.

“But the big disappointment was I thought their goal should not have been allowed.

“Huth’s got two hands on Collins’ shoulders and there’s no way he could get off the ground.

“I also felt the free-kick leading up to it was one of the softest I’ve seen this season.

“Gardner never moved. He concentrated on the ball, kept his hands at his side and Pennant got in front of him and used his experience to get the foul.

“I’m aggrieved at that but they’re a dangerous team and they work it well.”

McLeish must have feared his young side, with seven Academy graduates on show, would eventually buckle at a Stoke set-piece.

They have now conceded a frightening 21 goals from set-pieces this season and again it proved their undoing.

McLeish’s misery was compounded by injuries to Stephen Warnock, who will have X-rays on an injured ankle and Chris Herd, who was taken to hospital complaining of feeling sick after taking a knock on the head.

Stoke boss Tony Pulis was delighted with his team’s comeback.

He insisted: “We lack lot things but the one thing you can never criticise us for is a lack of effort.

“After getting to 41 points against Wolves on Saturday there could have been that feeling of: ‘We’re there, we can just put our sandals on now and wait for our holidays when we can fly out of England.’

“Sometimes the players — especially from me — don’t get the credit they deserve. We’re not ones for blowing smoke up our own backsides.”

Perhaps we should have expected a point apiece as Villa are the undisputed draw kings of the Premier League.

This was their FOURTEENTH draw of the season but the one thing they couldn’t draw was a bumper Bank Holiday crowd as the 30,100 attendance was Villa’s lowest home gate in the league this season.

There was an end of season feel to the proceedings early on as both teams played cat-and-mouse with each other.

Warnock was booked after eight minutes when he chopped down Ryan Shotton at the second attempt near the right touchline.

But it was 10 more minutes before either team managed a shot on target. Even then, James Collins’ back-post header failed to trouble Asmir Begovic.

At the other end Jon Walters set up Kenwyne Jones with a cute backheel on the edge of the box but the £8million Trinidadian blasted his shot harmlessly into the side netting.

The game desperately needed a shot in the arm. And kid striker Andi Weimann delivered in style as Villa took the lead after 32 minutes.

The home side worked a throw-in on the left to the hitman who turned sharply and played a crisp one-two with Stephen Ireland.

Despite a packed Potters defence in front of him the 20-year-old curled an exquisite right-foot shot high into the top corner beyond Begovic’s despairing dive.

It was the former Rapid Vienna youngster’s second goal in his last five Villa outings, one month on from the dramatic injury-time winner which earned three vital points against Fulham.

The youngster has answered McLeish’s SOS for a goal-scorer to stand in for long-term crock Darren Bent.

As Stoke wobbled Barry Bannan produced an inviting cutback which Jon Walters sliced dangerously close to his own goal to Begovic’s discomfort.

Collins then slashed an angled shot over after Bannan’s corner had been knocked down to him.

Stand-in left-back Eric Lichaj earned Villa’s second booking for pulling down Rory Delap as he attempted to break free with Stoke trying to step up the pace.

Keeper Shay Given then clawed away a wicked Shotton cross at full-stretch.

And Huth should have done better than head wide from six yards after he got on the end of Matthew Etherington’s inswinging corner.

Stoke came even closer to an equaliser just on half-time when Walters’ glancing header scraped just over and landed on the roof of the net.

Villa almost added to their lead after 57 minutes when Warnock’s flick-on was knocked on by Weimann to Ireland whose first-time pass sent Gabby Agbonlahor clear.

But the Villa skipper’s shot drifted wide of the far post.

Warnock’s awkward landing saw him replaced by Gary Gardner while Pulis sent on Jermaine Pennant and Peter Crouch for Jones and Etherington.

It paid off as Pennant delivered the pinpoint free-kick which led to Stoke’s equaliser.

The winger whipped in a wicked centre and, from six yards, Huth climbed above Collins to power his close-range header high into the roof of the net.

pages.headline: Plucky 13
pages.teaser: MAN UTD legend reckons winning title this year could be his biggest achievement
pages.articlebody:
RYAN GIGGS has one hand on a 13th title medal — and believes this could be the sweetest of the lot.

The Welshman reckons it will be a massive achievement if Manchester United can end a challenging season by retaining their crown.

Giggs, 38, admits the champions have been hit hard by injuries to the likes of Nemanja Vidic and Darren Fletcher for large parts of the season.

They also waved goodbye to a wealth of experience in the summer — even though Paul Scholes was then lured out of retirement a few months later.

And, of course, they have had to topple neighbours Manchester City who began the season in such inspired fashion but now find themselves eight points adrift.

It all adds up to a brilliant effort from the Red Devils according to the Premier League’s most decorated player.

He said: “To win the title would be huge when you look at the spending power of Manchester City.

“You had to give credit to City at the start of the season as they were playing well and scoring lots of goals.

“Their key players were performing and they have a great squad, so even if they were going to get injuries or suspensions they were going to handle it.

“We just had to hang in there.

“But then there’s injuries we’ve had. We’ve not had the best luck this season — we’ve had injuries to key players such as Vidic and Fletcher.

“So a lot of credit has to go to the lads who have stepped in.”

In the early weeks of the campaign, it looked as though it could be a season of transition for Alex Ferguson’s champions.

Giggs added: “There was also the experience we’ve lost. Scholesy for half the season, Edwin van der Sar, John O’Shea, Wes Brown.

“Then the challenge we faced in bringing in a new goalkeeper.

“David de Gea came in for a lot of criticism early on but he’s worked hard and he’s showing terrific form at a key time.

“Then there’s all the new talent we’ve blooded so winning it would be a massive achievement.”

The return of fellow golden oldie Scholes has been the catalyst for an amazing run of form by the champions.

Since the 37-year-old midfielder came out of retirement in January, United have taken 34 points from a possible 36 to leave rivals Manchester City floundering.

And Giggs said: “Scholesy coming back was a massive bonus for us at the time, having him on the pitch and around the place in training. He’s still the best trainer — you can’t get the ball off him. He does things other players can’t do.”

Giggs has also been instrumental for United again — with his last-gasp winner at Norwich in February looking like one of the defining moments of the season.

He recalled: “You could see what it meant to us in the celebrations. It was pure emotion, pure relief.

“It was massively important and it definitely gave everyone in the squad, as well as the fans, a lift.

“You need those moments in a season if you are going to go on and win the league. Moments like that provide belief and boost confidence — just look at what Federico Macheda’s goal against Villa did for us a few years ago.

“Who knows? That game at Norwich may turn out to be one of those days we look back on as being pivotal.”

In this kind of form, United seem highly unlikely to take their eye off the ball and let their eight point lead slip.

But Giggs insists his team-mates will not take anything for granted between now and the end of the season on May 13.

That run in starts against Wigan tomorrow night. And Giggs added: “You concentrate on doing your thing and looking after your own form personally and as a team. That is what we’ve done.

“We are experienced enough to know that there are still plenty of points to be gained and lost.

“Until it is mathematically impossible for us to be caught, we won’t be counting our chickens. We never do.”

“The key word is momentum. We’ve chased down teams before and been chased down ourselves.

“What you’re looking for is a bit of form at the right time and then feed off positive results and go on a roll.

“I think we’re doing that at the moment.”

BRANISLAV IVANOVIC will miss Chelsea’s next three games after punching Wigan’s Shaun Maloney.

Referee Mike Jones missed the incident in the build-up to Juan Mata’s stoppage-time winner on Saturday.

But eagle-eyed Match of the Day viewers saw Ivanovic punching Maloney in the stomach off the ball.

And the Serbian defender will be hit with a three-match ban for violent conduct when the footage is viewed by the FA’s disciplinary panel today.

He will miss Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final against Spurs at Wembley as well as vital Prem games against Arsenal and QPR.

pages.headline: Milner is on the money
pages.teaser: MANCHESTER CITY midfield star admits know how in the heat of title run-in counts most
pages.articlebody:
JAMES MILNER admits there is still one thing in football you cannot buy — League titles.

Manchester City’s late slump proves the Prem crown is worth more than a quick buck.

Midfielder Milner said: “For the last 20 years, Manchester United have got that knack of winning and know how to close out title races.

“This is the first year we’ve been up there as a group.

“We have brought players in and it takes time for them to settle. As a team, to keep improving you have to work hard and be together for a number of years.”

City, who play West Brom tomorrow, have splashed £210million in two years under Roberto Mancini.

Milner added: “Whatever happens this season, whether we win it or don’t, we have to make sure we learn from the good and the poor things which have gone on.”

pages.headline: Coppell returns at Crawley Town
pages.teaser: STEVE COPPELL is back in football as the new director of football at Crawley Town
pages.articlebody:
STEVE COPPELL is back in football as the new director of football at Crawley Town.

The move comes after Steve Evans left his job as manager of the League Two to take over the same role at Rotherham.

A Crawley statement said: "Steve will oversee all aspects of the club's football operations.

"Craig Brewster will remain as caretaker manager."

Coppell has had stints as manager of clubs including Manchester City, Crystal Palace and most recently Bristol City.

Former Inverness and Dundee United boss Brewster was handed the temporary job yesterday.

Crawley currently stand fourth, with three teams going straight up to League One.

Former England and Manchester United winger Coppell, 56, has led both Palace and Reading into the Premier League in his career as a manager.

But he has been out of the game since leaving Bristol City in August 2010, after less than four months in charge.

At the time, Coppell said he was retiring from managing but hoped to find another role within football.

Crawley chief executive Alan Williams said: "Bringing someone with Steve's stature in football as well as his experience and detailed knowledge of the game to Crawley Town is another important milestone in the development of the club.

"Steve's background and pedigree will help us to achieve our aims of pushing into League One and beyond.

"I am sure his appointment will be welcomed by everyone with Crawley Town FC at heart."

pages.subdeck: IN CONTROL ... Thomas Vermaelen wants Arsenal to remain strong in run-in
pages.headline: Threesy target by Tom
pages.teaser: BELGIAN defender says maximum points is a must to beat Tottenham into third spot
pages.articlebody:
THOMAS VERMAELEN last night told his Arsenal team-mates they must win ALL their remaining games to pip Tottenham for third in the Premier League.

The see-saw battle between the North London rivals looks to have swung Arsenal’s way after Spurs’ home loss to Norwich.

But the Belgian centre-half is not convinced.

Vermaelen, 26, said: “That is what we play for, the battle for third place.

“That gives us direct qualification for the Champions League. That is very important for the club and is our main target.

“I hear it every day on the streets. Fans ask us to be above Tottenham. If we win every game, we will do it.”

Robin van Persie, with 33 Arsenal goals this season, has failed to score in four games and yet the Gunners have won three of them.

Vermaelen said: “He’s not scored for a while but that’s not important while the team wins games.

“If he doesn’t score, we have to make sure other players do.”

Vermaelen insisted the Gunners can challenge for the title next season but they must cut out unexpected defeats.

He added: “You must be consistent in the league and sometimes that’s not been the case. We will try to do better next year. I’m confident we can.”
