pages.teaser: LIVERPOOL boss wants answers from officials who are wrecking their season
pages.articlebody:
KENNY DALGLISH has hit out at officials who are wrecking their season.

But Liverpool boss Dalglish warned his stumbling stars they cannot listen to the conspiracy theories if they hope to halt their slump.

Dalglish reckons his side have been denied blatant penalties in the last two games against Villa and Newcastle, as well as having a disallowed goal in the home defeat to Wigan.

But the players cannot feel sorry for themselves ahead of Saturday’s FA Cup semi with Everton.

Dalglish said: “In the last three games there have been blatant decisions against us which are inexcusable.

“It would be helpful and more transparent if refs explained the decisions to us, or even held their hands up to say ‘Sorry I got that wrong.’

“Then we could at least see they have the integrity, but they never say anything.

“We don’t get everything right, do we, so it’s understandable if they don’t either.

“But a wee bit of respect towards us would help, otherwise people may think there’s a conspiracy.

“That’s something we cannot believe, it’s something we can’t let affect us because it would damage us.”

STEVE KEAN fears slow-starting Blackburn could get left behind in the survival race.

The manager is looking to halt a run of three straight defeats at home to Liverpool tonight.

Rovers lost 3-0 to West Brom on Saturday and were behind after just seven minutes.

Kean said: “We must address the way we are starting games. The mindset isn’t to start slow.

“We have to spark into life a bit quicker. We can certainly start quick in the second half so why not in the first half?”

One of the best results of Kean’s tenure came in a 3-1 win over Liverpool in January 2011.

Kean said: “There’s no reason why we can’t beat Liverpool again. It is not going to be easy to stay up but there are plenty of points to play for.”

pages.headline: Oh Yes
pages.teaser: ALLYSON FELIX thinks Olympic 400m champion can spring a surprise this summer
pages.articlebody:
CHRISTINE OHURUOGU can spring a surprise at London 2012 — insists American rival Allyson Felix.

Ohuruogu is Britain's only defending Olympic champion on the track but she has struggled to find her form since Beijing 2008.

After suffering a string of injuries she then famously false-started in the HEATS of the one-lap event at last summer's World Championships.

But last month Ohuruogu ran a storming leg of the 4x400m relay at the World Indoors — her first outing at the competition — to help win gold.

British head coach Charles van Commenee has already claimed that the Stratford athlete, who won the 400m world crown outdoors in 2007, is back to her best having watched her in training.

And Felix, who won 400m world silver last summer and is a pal of the British runner after they met warm weather-training, said: "The brilliant thing about Christine is that somehow she manages to put together these amazing races when it counts.

“There’s nothing like competing in a home Olympic Games and since she’s already won Olympic gold maybe she’ll feel less pressure.

“There are a lot of different medal contenders and the attention is not necessarily all on her so that could help in her favour as well.

“I wouldn’t count anyone out. I think she can do something special.”

Felix, 26, who is still chasing an Olympic individual title having won 200m silver in both Athens and Beijing, as well as 4x400m gold four years ago, said: "I didn’t even know she was going to be competing indoors but I caught her race and to be in that form so early in the season is great."

Felix doubled up in the 200m and 400m at the World Championships in Daegu last year but has not ruled out swapping the one-lap for the blue riband 100m this summer.

She said: “All I know is that I want individual Olympic gold — that’s always been my goal.

“I’ll run the 200m for sure and other than that I haven’t decided.

"I’m going to let my coach make the final decision right before the US trials. But he’s training me as if we’re going to do a double."

“The 400m is first and there’s just a day before the 200m begins — it’s an even a worse schedule than the World Championships.

"So the 100m is still on the table because it doesn’t take as much out of you.

“I’ve never run the 100m on a world stage but I’ve always loved it being a sprinter and I feel like I would be comfortable.”

JOB ROW

AUSSIE sports chief Matt Favier has accused Britain of holding back his Olympic preparations.

He was UK Sport performance boss until December but was not allowed to start his new job straight away.

Favier said: “It was very much gamesmanship on the part of the UK.”

CYCLING

ANNA MEARES is being backed to win gold at Victoria Pendleton’s expense at London 2012.

After losing to Pendleton at the world championships, the Aussie bounced back to win the keirin.

Her coach Kevin Tabotta insisted: “Anna knows she’s the fastest sprinter in the world.”

pages.subdeck: HOLE LOT OF TROUBLE ... Lee Westwood struggled on the Augusta greens
pages.headline: A putter shambles
pages.teaser: WESTY to look for new coach after sloppy work on greens cost him a Green Jacket
pages.articlebody:
LEE WESTWOOD will be in the market for a new putting coach after his sloppy work on the Augusta greens cost him a Green Jacket.

Westwood hit the ball better than anyone else at The Masters — he led the greens in regulation table — but only three players, among the 62 who played all four rounds, putted worse.

Westy, who finished two shots behind winner Bubba Watson and his play-off opponent Louis Oosthuizen, had an average of 32 putts a round.

His total of 128 was 21 more than Phil Mickelson and eight more than Watson — another dodgy putter.

Westy tried to address his problems on the green by hooking up with putting coach Phil Kenyon last year.

But Westwood’s manager, Chubby Chandler, made it clear the move had not worked — and that they would be looking elsewhere as the player seeks to end a record-breaking run of near-misses in the Majors.

Chandler said: “I don’t know how much difference Kenyon’s made. I don’t think he’s made any. Whether that stays the same or not, hmmm.

“But Lee will keep working. To finish as close as he did while taking 21 more putts than Phil is staggering.

“And I was surprised at how upbeat Lee was. He wasn’t beating himself up because he knows he cannot play much better.

“He said he either keeps plugging away until his turn comes or gives up. And he is no a quitter.

“The funny thing was that he putted better the more pressure he was under.

“He made four birdies in the last six holes. That’s encouraging.”

pages.articlebody:
WELCOME to the wacky world of Bubba golf – featuring the car from the Dukes of Hazzard, tears and a Green Jacket.

Bubba Watson used to be famous for his big hitting and his tendency to turn on the waterworks.

But the Masters winner is proud of the fact he has never had a golf lesson and recently bought the General Lee, the car from the TV show Dukes of Hazzard.

He said: “We always joked about Bubba golf.

“I just play the game, the game I love. And it’s like Seve played. He hit shots that were unbelievable. So that’s what I do.”

Watson and his wife Angie recently adopted a baby and the 33-year-old wept as he talked about becoming a father – just as he sobbed when his dad died of cancer two years ago.

He added: “My dad would be excited, just like my mom was.

“We just cried. I dreamed about winning The Masters — I just never made the putt.”
